dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOORLAND YORKSHIRE LATE WINTER AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A HIGH ANGLED SHOT of a young WOMAN dressed in the hiking style of the early thirties running across wild Moorland. We are too far away clearly to be able to identify her fa MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN HIKER is seen from the back, running through he and splashing through a stream MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN HIKER seen from the back climbs out of the stre and gains a rough track leading over a small stone bridge She runs over it and disappears into the melancholy countryside. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, YORKSHIRE VILLAGE HIGH STREET DUSK
dialogues.text: The village street is empty. Prominent is a Police Statio The WOMAN HIKER, again seen from the back, runs panting i it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE STATION EVENING
dialogues.text: A POLICE SERGEANT sits at a desk. The HIKER, again seen from the back, rushes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN HIKER
dialogues.text: Murder! ... Murder! ...You must come at once! There's a woman lying dead out at Marley Copse. I think she's been strangled.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YORKSHIRE MOORLAND NIGHT
dialogues.text: A HIGH SHOT of a police car racing through the countrysid It is driven by a POLICE CONSTABLE. Next to him is the POLICE SURGEON. Two figures are dimly perceived sitting i the back seat. One is the WOMAN HIKER. The other is helmeted. We hear their conversation, but never go inside the car, or get a clear view of the features of the WOMAN  6 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POLICE SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Now madam, what time did you say it was when you found the body?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN HIKER
dialogues.text: About a quarter past four ... I think she'd only just been killed.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE SERGEANT
dialogues.text: How did you know that? Did you see anybody hanging about?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN HIKER
dialogues.text: No. But she was still warm. The car races away from CAMERA, over the Moors.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARLEY COPSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: A torch breaks the darkness and lights up the distorted f of ALICE CORRIGAN. The strangled body lies in deepish bra Beside it kneels a POLICE SURGEON.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE SURGEON
dialogues.text: Let's see, It's now six o'clock. I'd say she'd been dead no more than two hours. Say four o'clock, as the outside for time of death.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE SERGEANT
dialogues.text: The young woman said she was still warm when she found her at four fifteen sir.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE SURGEON
dialogues.text: Well, so she would have been. Warm as toast.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE OF THE TROJAN INSURANCE COMPANY DAY
dialogues.text: A SENIOR EXECUTIVE of the Trojan Insurance Company sits a desk reading some papers. There is a knock at the door an looks up eagerly as a young female SECRETARY comes in.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Hercules Parrot, sir. The SECRETARY withdraws as HERCULE POIROT enters. He carr a folder of papers. The EXECUTIVE rises and indicates a c on the other side of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Good morning Monsieur Poirot. Please take a seat,  Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Bon Jour Monsieur. He sits in the proffered seat as the EXECUTIVE regains hi own chair.

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you have some good news for me.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Alas no. I regret that I can find nothing in these reports to justify my re-investigating this case for you. It is dll perfectly clear from the police reports. I know Mrs Alice Corrigan insured her life with your company, in her husband's favour, and that, he was the only person with a motive for killing her, but when it comes down to the copper tacks, he could not possibly have done so. Clearly on the evidence, the lady was murdered between four o'clock and four fifteen, when the body was found at Marley Copse. From two o'clock to four twenty, Mr Edward Corrigan was seen by at least half a dozen people to be on a train coming up from London. And the railway station was a good fifteen minutes walk from Marley Copse. Non, it is, parbleu, one of those rare cases where the Insurance Company must, aS you say, laugh and lump it. .

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Well if that's your view Monsieur Poirot, then I suppose we'll have to er - do just that. I must say I'm not surprised. The evidence is most conclusive. Still we had hoped ...

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: For a miracle? Alas it is not possible. 4s is most often the case in les affaires criminelles, the facts are exactly as they appear to be. I wish you good day, Monsieur. POIROT rises, bows and departs, leaving the folder of pap on the table. A SLOW MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  10 11 12 13 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An establishing SHOT of Smugglers' Island basking in the afternoons's sun. A rowing boat is approaching the Island with four figures in it. WE TRACK IN towards the nautical windows of the bar of the Jolly Roger Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE BAR OF THE JOLLY ROGER HOTEL LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE, a flamboyant fortyish ex-courtesan, now proprietress of the Jolly Roger Hotel stands in the bar straightening her hair, and generally putting the finishi touches to her appearance. It is about five o'clock on a summer's evening. She looks out of the bottle glass windo down at the strip of water which separates the Island fro the Mainland.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. THE SEA LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A SHOT of the rowing boat approaches the Island seen through the bottle glass windows from DAPHNE CASTLE's poi of view.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE BAR OF THE JOLLY ROGER HOTEL LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE reacts with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROWING BOAT LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: BILL the Boatman is rowing three guests across from the M land. He is a typical Salt. In the boat are MR and MRS ODELL GARDENER, an American couple from New York. She is large, with blue rinsed hair and diamante spectacles worn a chain. He is thin, tall, slightly stooped and legalisti with a scrawny neck topped by a turtle shaped head. The last occupant of the boat is MISS AGNES BREWSTER, an athletic, middle~aged spinster, who cloaks her vulnerabil under a gruff manner.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: (looking towards the Island) Ah! Smugglers’ Island! My, doesn't it look romantic. I can just see Warner Baxter and Elissa Landi in a movie, set here, can't you Odell?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Yes dear.  13 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: It would have to be something; like the kidnapping of a Sheik's daughter by a brigand of the sea ... Oriental Pride yields to Piratical kisses in a duel of male might and female charm. An exotic drama of love's sublime cruelty. She sighs rapturously.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I believe they have already used those particular phrases to describe the motion picture "In Her Arms" dear, though I pelieve on that occasion they were Parisian kisses to which Oriental Pride yielded.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: (firmly) Well never mind about that Odell. In the Jolly Roger Hotel it would darn well yield to a Pirate's busses. (to Miss Brewster) We're Myra and Odell Gardener by the way. From New York City. MR and MRS GARDENER extend their hands. MISS BREWSTER sha

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: How do you do, I'm Agnes Brewster. I hope you are enjoying your holiday.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: It's been just great. We've been doing England. MISS BREWSTER And have you done it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Sure. Canterbury Cathedral. The Crown Jewels, Lords Croquet Ground, though those gentlemen weren't playing the day we were there - you know the whole box of tricks. But enough is enough. Last week I said to Mr Kelso at Cooks, sight seeing is all very well, but all I want now is to get to some quiet spot in the Mediterranean and just relax. Mind you, I said not just anywhere. Oh no. It had to be sanitary. A cousin of Odell's went to a place in Wales last year where they only had an earth closet. Isn't it so Odell?  13 14 «EXT. Continued

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Two earth closets I think it was, dear. One for the guests and one for the servants. Mind you, I believe it was very picturesque.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: (sharply) Picturesque or not, you'd think at least they'd have been able to provide the paying customers with a water closet. (to Miss Brewster) You British sometimes take this Olde Worlde charm to quite ludicrous lengths.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: It's just that we don't believe in pampering ourselves that's all. It's my belief that all that central heating you have in America saps the energy of the nation, aside from being extremely bad for the complexion, It encourages -acne in the young, and craters in the not so young. (to Bill the Boatman) Come along Boatman, dig those oars in! Pull with a will! BILL gives her a sour look and rows even more lethargical than he has been doing. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: THE TERRACE OF THE JOLLY ROGER HOTEL LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE stands on the terrace of the Jolly Roger Ho welcoming MR and MRS GARDENER and MISS BREWSTER. In the background two servants BERT and CHARLIE struggle up the steps from the tiny harbour to the hotel carrying baggage

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I am Dapline Castle, let me welcome you to Smugglers' Island. I do hope you'll be most comfortable here.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I think Mr and Mrs Gardener are a little concerned about earth closets.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Earth closets! What can you possibly mean Miss Brewster?  14 15 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should explain that my wife is somewhat suspicious of lavatorial systems which are not indigenous to the United States of America, Mrs Castile.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: (to Mrs Gardener) I'm sure you will find all the loos here perfectly adequate Mrs Gardener. We even bave bidets in all the bath- rooms, If you will please follow me. DAPHNE CASTLE moves off towards the hotel, followed by MISS BREWSTER.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: I tend to believe that bidets are basically un-American, Odell. Still I suppose we'll have to put up with them. The GARDENERS follow the others towards the Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROWING BOAT LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: BILL rows his boat towards Smugglers’ Island. It contains MR BLATT, a jolly, coarse, life-and-soul-of-the-party, se made man, and PATRICK REDFERN and his wife CHRISTINE REDF He is a good looking young Irishman, fair-haired, and athletic. She is fair skinned, pleasant looking in a somewhat washed-out way. They are sitting in a reserved silence. MR BLATT inevitably decides to start the ball rolling.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Well, well, well! Might as well break the ice. Blatt's the name. Horace Blatt. Beef or mutton. L for leather. Aphorism. Tea for two, twice. Got it? He laughs considerably at his own oft repeated witticism.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: I'm Patrick Redfern, and this is my wife Christine. They smile at each other.  15 16 17 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: A Mick?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well I come from Dublin actually, but I haven’t been back for years.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: I say, I say, I say. How do you make an Irishman burn his ear?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Ring him up when he's ironing. It wasn't very funny when I first heard it five years ago. MR BLATT, crushed, looks away towards the Island.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR AND VIEW OF BEDROOMS EVENING
dialogues.text: The two servants BERT and CHARLIE are putting the luggage the allocated bedrooms. WE TRACK DOWN a long corridor following DAPHNE CASTLE to see through open doors that MR AND MRS GARDENER, MISS BREWSTER and MR HORACE BLATT have already established themselves in their rooms. Unpacking has started, and we hear the sound of baths being run. She approaches the REDFERNS' room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MR AND MRS REDFERNS' BEDROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: MR and MRS REDFERN are starting to unpack. CHARLIE is just retiring through the open door, as DAPHNE CASTLE app in it.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Mr and Mrs Redfern?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I'm Daphne Castle - the Pirate Chief. Welcome to Smugglers' Island.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Thank you. It all looks marvellous. I'm sure we'll have a nice time here.  17 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well a bit naughty I hope too.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Naughty?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well what are hols for if one can't do a bit of flirting, and get a bit pissyboos?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Quite right. - CHRISTINE shoots her husband a venomous look.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Yes, when fate cast me up here on this old rock, I said to myself people are going to have fun in a crazy old English atmosphere even though it's in the Med. So you'll find the servants are all English and properly trained, and there's lots of games to play and of course there's great grub.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Ah now we're talking. Most English hotels fall down in that department. Cold mutton and cabinet pudding are not my idea of holiday nourishment.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I don't think you'll find that either dish features on darling Andrea's menus. Let's face it, he is almost the greatest saucier in the Aegean. I say almost, because he does have a slightly hysterical hand with the créme fraiche, But it is a fault on the right side. See you for cocktails around seven. She breezes out.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Funny lady. He takes a robe and swimming trunks from his suitcase and goes into the bathroom.  17 18 19 10 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What do you think she meant by fate casting her up on this old rock?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Don't you know the story? She used to be the mistress of King Zog of Albania, and when he married he gave her this island.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Provided she kept away, I suppose. Generous fellow.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Wise fellow. Wives don't much like girl friends hanging around the place - or didn't you know that either? PATRICK REDFERN walks into the room, wearing only a swimm costume. and carrying his robe. We note his fine physique There is a moment of tension between them.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Yes, I had noticed. Toodle doo. He leaves the room jauntily. CHRISTINE looks after him speculatively then moves to the window to look out. Her face hardens at what she sees.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SMALL HARBOUR EVENING
dialogues.text: We see the harbour from CHRISTINE REDFERN's point of view The rowing boat is just being made fast by BILL. In it ar CAPTAIN KENNETH MARSHALL, a well groomed slightly stern man of about forty five years old, his wife ARLENA MARSHA a tall stunning red head of about thirty years old, and his daughter (her step daughter) LINDA MARSHALL, @ gauche unformed, unhappy girl of fifteen or so.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE JETTY IN THE HARBOUR EVENING
dialogues.text: The MARSHALLS step ashore. At the same moment PATRICK RED passes them on a path which leads down to the Hotel Beach He stops when he catches sight of ARLENA, his face regist surprised delight. Then his gaze travels uneasily to her husband and back again, to ARLENA.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Why hullo Arlena.  11 19 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Dahling! Fancy meeting you here, of all places. What an astounding coin- eidence.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: By St. Patrick himself and all the snakes in Ireland it is that.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Do you know my husband, Kenneth?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Hullo there.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Patrick and I met in London at the Gordons a couple of weeks ago. You remember, I told you about it, Ken. They had that marvellous Josephine Baker singing there. She sings Les Mots D'Amour, directing it in a very obviou way at PATRICK REDFERN. Quite abruptly she stops singing suddenly There is turns on LINDA.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: This is my step-daughter Linda, Cloud aside to Linda) Stop standing there all pink and sticky like a half eaten’ marshmallow, and say good evening to Mr Redfern.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Good evening Linda. an awkward moment of tension.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well I'll be taking myself off to have my dip. See you all later. ARLENA MARSHALL looks after him appreciatively, as he wal off down towards the beach. Her husband and step daughter regard her with somewhat less than the same pleasure. The  19 20 21 12 Continued CAMERA PANS round and tracks in towards CHRISTINE REDFERN window, to see her still standing at it looking down. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROWING BOAT EVENING
dialogues.text: BILL rows his boat raggedly towards the Island. In the stern sits HERCULE POIROT in acute distress.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ma foie. Cannot you row this boat more calmly?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Gawd bless you sir. It's calmer than a cup of tea today.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I have never found anything calming about a cup of tea. It is simply a device used by the English to underscore tension.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well you ought to see it somedays ~- waves like roller coasters! POIROT groans and clasps his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUN LOUNGE EVENING
dialogues.text: In the glassed in sun lounge DAPHNE CASTLE's cocktail par is in full swing. MR and MRS GARDENER are talking to MR and MRS REDFERN and MISS BREWSTER. CAPTAIN MARSHALL and h daughter are talking to each other. DAPHNE CASTLE and a COUPLE OF MAIDS - GLADYS NORRACOTT, and BETTY TRUMBLE - are moving anxiously through the room serving canapes and drinks. In the general chatter of conversation we pas close by HORACE BLATT telling POIROT a dirty joke.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: You see this feller comes running down the hospital corridor, holding his privates, pursued by the nurse carrying a bowl of boiling water. And following them is the doctor yelling "No nurse. What I said was prick his boil". .  21 13 Continued MR BLATT collapses into gales of laughter and moves away. The CAMERA TRACKS into a CLOSE UP of a baffled POIROT as he is joined by DAPHNE CASTLE and BETTY TRUMBLE holdin a tray of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: How about a cocktail Monsieur Poirot?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: What would you suggest, Madame? DAPHNE CASTLE points to the various glasses on the tray a she names them.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: A White Lady? A Sidecar? A Mainbrace? A Between The Sheets? A King Zog? POIROT examines the last named in its tall frosted glass, dubiously. :

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And what might be in that one Madame?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Mostly 151% Bacardi -Arejo Rum. It'll grow hair on your eyeballs.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I do not believe that my eyes need to be that guarded, Madame, but if you have a little Creme de Cassis, or perhaps a Sirop de Fraises, I should be most content.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) Sounds a bit soppy to me but I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Merci, Madame. BETTY TRUMBLE leaves with her tray of drinks to circulate through the party. She is replaced at a sign from DAPHNE CASTLE by GLADYS NORRACOTT bearing a tray of Canapés. Prominent are some multicoloured ones, and others formed into the shape of smiling black faces.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Meanwhile how about a Rainbow's End, or a nice Birmingham Smile. They're both tres Muresque - you know, very moreish.  21 14 Continued The dish of canapes is proffered and POIROT takes one. DAPHNE CASTLE's attention is distracted by MR and MRS RED who are in animated conversation with the GARDENERS, and a bright backwards looking smile at POIROT she swoops dow on them.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Ah, Mr Redfern, what did I tell you. Everybody enjoys themselves here. It's not called the Jolly Roger for nothing - even though the name might be said to be more appropriate to an amusing brothel. Behind her POIROT bites into his canape. Creamed Crab spurts out over the lapel of his jacket. The CAMERA MOVES with DAPHNE CASTLE as she joins KENNETH and LINDA MARSHAL In the background POIROT dabs ruefully at his clothing wi a handkerchief, and unashamedly listens.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: By Jove, Daphne, you've been successful since we last met - how long ago is it?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: It must be a good seventeen years Linda certainly wasn't born. As a matter of fact I don't think you'd even married your first wife then.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: No, I don't think I had. Poor Mary she had such an unhappy life. But let's not talk about her. Let's talk about you. You're rich and famous - everyone’s heard about this crazy hotel of yours - it's always in the glossies.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Poor and infamous you mean. They laugh intimately together. Seriously, you shouldn't believe every- thing you hear Kenneth. I'm not that much changed from the daft Daphne you used to know at Shipley.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Were you at Shipley? Daddy's told me so much about it.  21 22 15 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Yes, we were neighbours for years. Do you remember the day we took Toby down to the river to get water rats, and you pushed me in in my best dress?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Absolutely. And you flew into the most frightful rage, and half choked me to death,

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Not me, It's impossible. The only attack I've ever made on anyone was when I threw my spaghetti alla yongole at Mussolini for trying to grope me under the table in the Vatican.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What rot! You used to fly into the most fearful rages in those days. We all had to watch our ps and qs a bit. Ah here comes Arlena now ... ARLENA MARSHALL enters the room. She is dramatically attired and gorgeous to look at. Conversation ceases on t instant as all eyes turn towards her. PATRICK REDFERN takes a few steps in her direction, his arms outstretched and we freeze the picture. A series of quick cuts establish the company's reactions. SLOW MIX THROUGH to the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: HERCULE POIROT arrayed in a white duck suit lies in a dec chair surveying the sunlit scene below. Sunbathing on the beach are MR and MRS REDFERN (the latter in the shade of umbrella), HORACE BLATT, KENNETH MARSHALL and LINDA MARSH and MR and MRS GARDENER. DAPHNE CASTLE is swimming. MISS BREWSTER sits beside POIROT on the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I understand you are a very distinguished detective Monsieur Poirot.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: People have been felicitous enough to have told me that I have some slight skill in that metier, Madame.  16 22 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I do hope we 're not going to have any bodies on Smugglers' Island.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Let me assure you Madame I am here simply to spend the holiday. I do not even think of crime. And yet as to bodies, what are they? He points down to the beach below. Regard them there lying out in rows like corpses in the morgue. They are not men and women. There is nothing personal about them. They are just bodies, like butchers' meat on Slabs. Chunks of flesh grilling in the sun. When I was young one barely saw even the ankle.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (firmly) I must say though that I think the things we wear nowadays are much more sensible. The air must be allowed to circulate freely round the body. A healthy mind in a healthy body, that's my motto and I keep mine healthy rowing. POIROT looks down self-consciously at his expansive paunc MISS BREWSTER notices.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: You'd soon have that off if you rowed Monsieur Poirot.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle I detest boats. I have the mal de mer. Even my bath gives me sea sickness. On the beach we see CHRISTINE REDFERN get up from under h umbrella,.and start to walk up the steps towards the hote PATRICK REDFERN goes down the beach to swim. The CAMERA ZOOMS in for a moment to isolate him as he plunges in and starts to swim, using a powerful crawl stroke.  22 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (half Voice Over Patrick Redfern swimming and half direct speech) How unfortunate. I suppose it's a bit like heights. Some people can't stand them. I'm not very good myself, but Mrs Redfern is far worse. Why only this morning on the cliff path above Keelhaul Caves, she turned giddy and simply clung to me, quite unable to move. 17 CHRISTINE REDFERN comes up to the group. Her skin noticea very white, Hullo dear. We were just talking about you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: It's a wonder my ears weren't burning. Everywhere else does, so easily.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You don't like the sunbathing, Madame?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: I only wish I could but I don't go brown. I just become like a cassata ~ pink skin, white blisters, and green in the face. Polite laughter while she puts on her robe. Isn't it blissful here. So tranquil. So far away from all trouble and violence.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It is true the sky is blue, and the sun shines, but you forget Madame, everywhere there is evil under the sun. ARLENA MARSHALL walks down from the hotel to the beach, passing the group. She is very suntanned, and wears a bac less white bathing suit. On her head she wears a fantasti Chinese hat of jade green cardboard. She moves with super assurance and the whole effect is rather like a stage ent

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ah, Madame Marshall! What was her stage name?  22 23 24 18 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (sharply) Arlena Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Oh yes. I saw her in Come and Go a couple of years ago at the Alhambra, It was trés charmant. Did you ever see her Mademoiselle?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I was employed by her once, and she is not charmant Monsieur Poirot, believe me. She's poisonously rotten through and through.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Is it possible, Mademoiselle?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Yes. I was her secretary for over five years. I tell you she can be a remorseless fiend. She wants every- thing for herself. She'll give nothing to anybody else ~- no references, no help. And she'll-.use any device to prevent you telling the truth about her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOOTY BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: ARLENA MARSHALL has reached the beach, and stands irresol looking about her. PATRICK REDFERN swims back to the beac with powerful, flamboyant strokes, as if drawn towards he by a magnet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: The group of POIROT, MISS BREWSTER and CHRISTINE REDFERN is as it was before in Scene 22.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: What you say is truly shocking Mademoiselle. Don't you think so Madame Redfern? CHRISTINE REDFERN gets to her feet and waves to her husba In the distance we see him pause, then ignore the wave, a deliberately walk off with ARLENA MARSHALL down the beach Abruptly. CHRISTINE REDFERN turns and leaves the terrace, heading back towards the hotel.  24 25 19 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I think I shall go for my row now. MISS BREWSTER rises and walks off the terrace in the dire of the small harbour. Slowly POIROT shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais oui. Undoubtedly there is the smell of evil here. POIROT struggles out of the deck chair and strolls down t steps towards the beach.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOOTY BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE comes out of the sea. Her bathing suit is outstandingly chic. Her gaze is alternating between KENNETH MARSHALL who is lying next to his daughter on the sand taking the sun, and ARLENA MARSHALL and PATRICK REDF who are sitting and talking further down the beach, as POIROT strolls up to her.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Good morning Mademoiselle. What a charming costume.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Why thank you Monsieur Poirot.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: The bathing costume can be so un- flattering n'est ce pas?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: (looking at Arlena) It is my opinion that ninety eight percent of all the people in this world should never put one on.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mrs Marshall of course being one of the remaining two percent.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Obviously. It's one of a couple of activities she does to perfection.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: The other being?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Adultery.  20 25 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: So you think your old friend of seventeen years ago has made the mistake in marrying her eh? She shoots him a shrewd look.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: A mistake? It's a silver plated, copper bottomed, gilt-edged, disaster. Still it probably suits him. He always was a collector of lame ducks.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: She doesn't look much like le canard poiteux, to me.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Ob you don't understand. He married his first wife simply because no one elise would have her, and when she died he upped and married that shop- worn piece of fluff when she was jilted by Lord Coddington after being cited in his divorce.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Well perhaps Mademoiselle, she makes him the good wife.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Good wives, as they say in Italy, do not grow horns on their husbands' heads. Why only last year that randy old fool Sir George Barry left her every penny of his money, - about one hundred thousand pounds by all account - enough to keep her in single chins for life and I tell you, she didn't get that for her racing tips. Now it looks as if she's got her claws into Patrick Redfern, and that poor wife of his hasn't the faintest idea of how to remove them. It's a pity really, but in the end I suppose all ladies have to learn to defend what they want. Don't you agree Monsieur Poirot. She smiles at POIROT mischievously and walks off along th beach to join KENNETH MARSHALL, POIROT looks after her thoughtfully. He sees LINDA MARSHALL get up and run down the beach towards where PATRICK REDFERN and ARLENA MARSHA  25 21 Continued are talking. Slowly he walks in the same direction. MR BLATT comes splashing up from the sea, in a loud striped bathing suit which makes him look like a corpulent wasp, and intercepts POIROT.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: He roars

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Good morning Monsieur P. I see they won't get you in the briny in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Non. I have never cared for la mer.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Well I suppose you can't teach an old frog new tricks eh? laughs uproariously. HERCULE POIROT is scandalized.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: An old frog? ... What can this mean?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Frog ... Froggie ... You know - Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (coldly) I am not old, and I am not a Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Monsieur, I am a Belgian.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: I beg pardon. I thought they were all the same, vieux haricot.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Vieux haricot - Old Bean - get it? with laughter again, towelling himself vigorously as he does so. POIROT nods in mystification.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Care to join me for a pre-lunch livener?  25 22 Continued POIROT still looks bemused, so MR BLATT mimes the action drinking.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ah l'aperitif. Une bonne idee, Before turning back towards the hotel, POIROT looks down beach to where LINDA has joined her step-mother and PATRI REDFERN about thirty yards away. The CAMERA ZOOMS in to j them.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: {to Linda) What the hell are you doing here Linda? Did your father send you to play goose- berry, chaperon, or spy?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (panting) I thought I'd just come for a chat Arlena. I don't seem to be having any fun.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Well why don't you go back to the hotel, dahling, and write out five hundred times, I must try not to look so abysmally dowdy, and if you take your own advice you may just get to have some. LINDA flees awkwardly away down the beach towards where POIROT and MR BLATT are starting their walk towards the swimming pool bar. She is sobbing and cursing under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (to Patrick Redfern) Really, that girl runs like a diseased dromedary. The CAMERA ZOOMS BACK to its previous position. As she passes POIROT and MR BLATT we hear distinctly what she is saying.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: The bitch! ... I could kill her! ... I could kill her! POIROT shakes his head at MR BLATT who looks away in embarrassment. They continue their walk towards the bar as the CAMERA PANS off them to where DAPHNE CASTLE is sitting on the beach talking to KENNETH MARSHALL.  23 25 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I know it's none of my business, but if I may presume on an old friendship, I'd like to ask you why you put up with her?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Arlena of course, She does make you look a bit cheapyboos.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I suppose she does. Still I can cope with it.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Do you think Linda can?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well, she's always on at the child, bitching the hell out of her.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yes. It's a pity about that. Linda's like her mother. She takes things hard.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Then why not do something about it?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Like what for instance?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Like fixing up a divorce for instance. People do it all the time you know - with most of my friends it's almost a full time occupation.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Not with me. A deal's a deal. I don't approve of quick marriage and easy divorce. Arlena is my wife, and that's all there is to it.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Till death do you part?  25 26 27 24 Continued

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I see.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SEA NEAR THE BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: MR and MRS GARDENER are on a pedal float. MRS GARDENER does the talking while MR GARDENER does the pedalling. Th pass the spot on the beach where ARLENA MARSHALL is talki to PATRICK REDFERN. As they go by, ARLENA takes PATRICK's arm and walks him down the beach, carefully keeping the hand which tickles his neck, screened from her husband.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Look at that. Still up to her old tricks. She hasn't changed a bit. She's man mad ... How much was it she cost us?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: And the lawyers' fees. Don't forget the lawyers' fees. How much did you pay Kleinfeld Klauswitz and Stummerhofen? -

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Another ten, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Exactly. Making sixty in all, I could wring her neck. She spits violently into the water.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: PATRICK REDFERN and ARLENA MARSHALL walk up to where KENNETH MARSHALL and DAPHNE CASTLE sit together on the beach.  27 25 Continued PATRICK REDFERN waves his hand awkwardly and continues wa on towards the hotel. KENNETH MARSHALL rises and draws AR a@ little apart from DAPHNE CASTLE.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You were very keen that we came here, Now I know why,

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yes. You knew that Redfern fellow was coming here, didn't you? All that baloney when we arrived, about coincidence .,.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Dahling, I swear to you it was the greatest possible surprise. You could have knocked me down with an orchid,

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I might just knock him down, and it won't be with anything frail or fancy either.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Dahling, you're so impetuous You know I don't care for anyone but you, She kisses him lightly. He stares blankly pack at her.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You know I often think Arlena that other people are right, and that I'd be much better off without you.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: My dahling what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I'm saying that you behave unkindly towards my daughter, and that you do me no credit whatsoever, She tosses her head and turns away from him to busy herse with the application of sun tan lotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POIROT and MR BLATT are in the swimming pool bar which is run by CHARLIE. MR BLATT drinks a pint of beer.  26 28 Continued POIROT holds a tiny, green, sticky aperitif. In the back- ground PATRICK REDFERN passes by and goes into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Tell me straight, Monsieur. What's a famous sleuth like you doing in a place like this?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Simply, I repose myself. I take les vacances.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: I suppose it was a stupid question really. You wouldn't tell me even if you were down 'ere on a job, would you now?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Possibly not, but I assure you it is not the case. And as for you, I could ask you the same question. I wouldn't have thought these people here were your tasse de the.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: You're right there. Bloody stand- offish the lot of them. No, frankly I came here because it sounded romantic, and well a bit daft - the Jolly Roger Hotel Smugglers' Island set in the Med! I've always had a bit of a thing about Pirates, ever since I was a boy sailing off the Cornish Coast. As a matter of fact I've hired a little yawl to do a spot of it 'ere. Perhaps you'd care to come for a spin this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Thank you, but no. I prefer the terra ferma. I wish I could oblige but there it is.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Talking of wishing, I'11 tell you the one about the bloke at the Wishing Well in Ireland. He's a bit upset you see, because sitting next to him is a titchy little piano player, about a foot high, piaying the old joanna for all its worth. And he's saying "No dammit, I did not wish for a twelve inch pianist."  28 29 30 27 Continued MR BLATT goes into gales of laughter. POIROT Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Well I wish I understood the English idiom better,

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Another snort? :

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Non merci. I shall put myself in order for lunch. POIROT gives MR BLATT a small bow and walks off towards t hotel.. WE TRACK INTO A CLOSE UP of MR BLATT'’s florid fa as his eyes narrow speculatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POIROT is walking along a path by the side of the hotel. stops to listen as raised voices float out from a first f bedroom window.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I tell you you're infatuated with her Pat. That's why you insisted on coming to this place - because you knew she'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What absolute rot! I hadn't the faintest idea.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don't lie. Whatever you do, don't lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATRICK REDFERN is facing his wife CHRISTINE. Both of them are standing near the open window.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Look here Christine, it's not like you to be jealous. Can't I speak to & pretty woman without you being after jumping to the conclusion I'm ... well, having an affair with her?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well aren't you?  30 31 32 33 28 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Of course not, Arlena and I are just friends that's all.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. Look, she's a bad lot, Pat. She'll do you harm - I know it. Please give it up, and let's go away from here.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: No. I absolutely refuse. Here we are, and here we stay. If you don't like it, you can ...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just stop being so bloody jealous. He stamps out of the room, banging the door, behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: That damned bitch ... I could murder her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POIROT, realising that the conversation has terminated continues on his way, sadly shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: MIX THROUGH TO
dialogues.text: A MONTAGE of evening activities in the lounge. LINDA MARSHALL reads a book. The GARDENERS, DAPHNE CASTLE and MISS BREWSTER play Mah Jong. : Next we glimpse MR BLATT and KENNETH MARSHALL playing billiards. POIROT watches these activites and then makes his way out of the hotel into the night.

dialogues.speaker: BAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: POIROT makes his way along a moonlit path which leads to Arbour situated above Bible Bay. There are marvellous  33 34 29 Continued views of the quiet silvered sea lapping an old stone Fisherman's Chapel. The bell on the top of it strikes eleven.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (to himself) The gentle moon, the lesser light. The Lover's Lamp, the Swain's delight, A ruined world, a globe burnt out, A corpse upon the road of night.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: (calling) Is anyone there? POIROT makes his way over to the Arbour which is construc of flowered trellis.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE ARBOUR NIGHT
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN sits on a stone bench gazing out over the sea. POIROT enters.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Forgive me if I startled you Madame. I was talking to the moon.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Oh the moon. I suppose everyone does that.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Everyone is a moon, Madame, and has a dark side which is never shown to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Everyone except me, I think. I wish I could be so secretive and not show what I feel.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Sometimes for ladies that is difficult.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Do you know what I'm most sick of in this place? :

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: What Madame?  30 34 Continued

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Pity. I can't bear to be pitied. Everyone around here is so sorry for me. I can tell by the way they look at me. Poor little thing, they're saying. What she has to put up with from that fool of a husband of hers.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Will you allow me to tell you something, Madame? The Arlena Stuarts of this world do not count. Their domination is of the moment. Really to count, & woman must have either goodness or brains,

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: You can't actually believe that men care for either of those things can you?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Yes I do. She laughs bitterly. Your husband loves you, Madame. I know it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: You can't know it. .

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: But I do. I've seen him looking at you. For Hercule Poirot, such an oeillade is enough. CHRISTINE REDFERN. breaks down and weeps on POIROT's shou After a while the weeping subsides.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: It's alright. I'm better now, Please leave me. I'd rather be alone. POIROT rises from the seat he has taken during her breakd offers her his bandana which she gratefully accepts, bows and retires.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PATH LEADING FROM BIBLE BAY TO THE HOTEL NIGHT
dialogues.text: POIROT walks thoughtfully along the path which leads from Bible Bay to the hotel. Suddenly he hears the sound of voices coming from behind some bushes, Cautiously he step aside to peer through.  36 37 38 31

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A TREE SCREENED CLEARING NIGHT
dialogues.text: In a little clearing screened from the Path by trees ARLE MARSHALL and PATRICK REDFERN stand close together. The latter's voice is loud and clear.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Arlena darling, you know I'm mad for you don't you ... I've quite looped the loop,

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Of course you are dahling. And I adore you too, my mad Irish, . She holds out her arms to him and they come together, embracing passionately.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PATH LEADING FROM BIBLE BAY TO THE HOTEL NIGHT
dialogues.text: POIROT, grimacing with embarrassment, hurries away toward the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Quelle vache de luxe! The elongated shadows of the entwined lovers writhe on th moonlit grass. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HOTEL NIGHT
dialogues.text: As POIROT nears the hotel he sees KENNETH MARSHALL standi outside it staring fixedly up at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Good evening Monsieur Poirot, What a lovely night. Not a breath of wind anywhere,

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: The calm before the storm perhaps, Bon nuit. He enters the hotel, and closes the door behind him. We m into a CLOSE UP of KENNETH MARSHALL's face to see it is suffused with bitterness and rage. He drives his balled fist into the palm of the other hand, making a sharp viol sound in the still night, SLOW MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  39 40 Al 42 32

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HARBOUR MORNING
dialogues.text: MR BLATT, whistling a cheerful hornpipe is making ready t cast himself off in a small yawl. He does so, raises the sails and moves out of the harbour, in a South Westerly direction. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OUTSIDE STAIRCASE THE HOTEL MORNING
dialogues.text: LINDA MARSHALL climbs the outside staircase. She wears a bathing costume.

dialogues.speaker: INT, HOTEL CORRIDOR MORNING
dialogues.text: LINDA MARSHALL steps into the corridor, and runs down it. She opens her bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LINDA MARSHALL'S BEDROOM MORNING
dialogues.text: LINDA comes into her bedroom. Inside CHRISTINE REDFERN stands awkwardly. LINDA MARSHALL is startled.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Oh there you are!

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yes ... Er, I thought I'd have an early dip.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Good idea. In fact I came in to ask you whether you'd like to come with me to Cutlass Cove this morning.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yes. I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Good, I'm playing tennis at twelve fifteen, so we'd better start fairly early. Half past ten suit you?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I'll be ready. Meet you in the hall, after breakfast. The door closes behind CHRISTINE REDFERN. LINDA MARSHALL looks after her puzzled.  43 33

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM MORNING
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS lovingly over a large selection of silver chafing dishes kept warm on a series of hot plates on the sideboard. We then CUT away to see DAPHNE CASTLE looking disapprovingly at LINDA MARSHALL who is listlessl finishing her meagre breakfast of coffee and toast.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: You know you really are naughty Linda. Andrea goes to all the trouble of preparing decent English breakfasts, instead of those weedy Continental affairs, and all you eat is toast.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Let me at least tempt you to Oeufs Jolly Roger.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What's that? DAPHNE CASTLE removes the cover from a dish and exhibits it.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: It's Andrea's lunatic idea of pirate gastronomy. Plover's eggs served in a sheep's skull with crossed marrow pones. Jolly tasty.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I just couldn't - really. DAPHNE CASTLE puts her arms round LINDA MARSHALL.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Is it Arlena?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (nodding bitterly) She's so beastly ...

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: You don't want to worry about her. Things have a habit of working out - I promise you.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Yes. If you make them!  45 46 35

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TERRACE OUTSIDE THE HOTEL MORNING
dialogues.text: HERCULE POIROT sits at a table under a beach umbrella dri a cup of coffee, and eating a croissant loaded with mount quantities of strawberry jam. DAPHNE CASTLE crosses from the hotel and heads off in a Westerly direction towards Lighthouse Ledge. CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL se off in a North Easterly direction towards Cutlass Cove. After a moment POIROT himself rises and moves off in a South Westerly direction towards Booty Beach.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOOTY BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: Booty Beach is empty save for ARLENA MARSHALL who is tryi to launch a float, She is dressed in the same white bathi Suit and green cardboard Chinese hat as the day previousl POIROT appears and stands watching her,

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Do you require assistance, Madame? ARLENA MARSHALL gives him one of her seductive looks.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Oh Monsieur Poirot, would you? I'm afraid it's a bit too heavy for me. POIROT walks down to the water's edge, but stops when he realises he is wearing white suede shoes. Gingerly he rem them, and puts them carefully with his socks, several fee beyond the tide mark. He then meticulously rolls up his trousers to the knees and walks into the sea. The float i successfully launched, and ARLENA MARSHALL, holding her paddle, jumps on it.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Thank you so much and Monsieur Poirot, please don't tell anyone where I've gone. Everyone will keep following me about so.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Everyone Madame?

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Well perhaps some people more than others, But I just want to be alone. With a bright and confiding smile on her face, ARLENA MARSHALL paddles away to the Northwards.  46 36 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (to himself) Ah, ca jamais! ... That I do not believe. She is not the Mademoiselle Garbo, that one. It is quite clear whom she is going to meet. He turns and retraces his steps towards the beach. His wh suede shoes float out to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacre Bleu! The suede is ruined. POIROT wades ashore mopping unhappily at his shoes. ARLEN MARSHALL's float rounds the point and disappears. A furth surprise greets POIROT as PATRICK REDFERN strolls down fr the direction of the hotel. He gapes first at REDFERN, th at the point which the float has just rounded.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: The top of the morning to you. You seem to have given your shoes a bath.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Alas it is so.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: You know you want to use a wire brush on those things. Salt water does them no good at all. He laughs delightedly. POIROT scowls.- After a moment or two REDFERN's mood changes, and he starts to look about h very obviously puzzled and impatient. KENNETH MARSHALL now approaches from the direction of the hotel. REDFERN eyes him apprehensively, but MARSHALL more or less ignore

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Morning Monsieur Poirot. Seen my wife about?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (innocently) Has Madame then arisen so early?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: She's not in her room ... I think I'll take my dip right away. I've got a lot of typing to do this morning. Can't abide it, but it's got to be done.  37 46 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You are perhaps an auteur?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: What me? Good gracious no. Perish the thought. No, they're pusiness letters. I sometimes think one would have a better holiday if one took one's secretary with one.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have thought that that was such an original thought, old boy.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: . (coldly) No, I daresay you wouldn't. MARSHALL takes off his robe and puts it on the sand, next Poirot's ruined shoes.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Hullo, hullo, hullo. Been taking your shoes for a swim?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (gritting his teeth) An unfortunate wave. KENNETH MARSHALL saunters off down to the sea. Behind the back of the unamused POIROT we see and hear MR and MRS GARDENER walking towards us. PATRICK REDFERN looks up eagerly, but is obviously disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And where is Madame Redfern this morning?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Who? ... Oh I don't know, I think she's gone off sketching somewhere, MR and MRS GARDENER come up with POIROT and PATRICK REDFE and sit down in beach chairs. MR GARDENER fusses about op beach umbrellas for his wife.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Good morning Mr Redfern. Good morning Monsieur Poirot. PATRICK REDFERN mumbles and POIROT bows. Have you been paddling, and forgotten to take your shoes off?  38 46 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Very drole Madame. He smiles thinly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: A friend of ours did something like that once in Miami. Do you remember Eileen Scholenblautwitz, Odell? Her old man gave her a watch for their wedding anniversary that must have cost a couple of arms and a leg, and she went into the water with it. When she came out she found of course that it wasn't working. Do you remember what she said? "The Godammed thing's stopped at eleven diamonds past three rubies".

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I thought it was in the morning dear, and she said "three rubies past eleven diamonds."

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: (firmly) It was in the afternoon Odell, and she said "eleven diamonds past three rubies",

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're right dear. We watch KENNETH MARSHALL swimming. He does it well, disappearing under the surface of the water for longish periods. A BRIEF MIX indicates a small time change. Finally he walks up the beach.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Hi there Captain Marshall! Where's Linda this morning?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Linda? ... I don't know. Mooning about the Island somewhere I expect.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: You know that girl looks kinda peaky to me. You ought to give her some of that Virol. They say anaemic girls need it. I*ve seen it on the hoardings. KENNETH MARSHALL finishes drying himself, and puts on his

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Linda's alright. Excuse me. I've got some work to do, and it's got a bit late.  39 46 Continued KENNETH MARSHALL walks away up the beach towards the hote

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: If you want my opinion, it's that step-mother of hers that's doing her no good. We knew an only child once whose father married again, didn't we Odell - remember Gloria Stuhlnichsteiner. She grew hair all over her bosom. We hear the sound of someone approaching, and PATRICK RED looks up hopefully, obviously to see if it is ARLENA MARS and then down again sulkily, as we see it is MISS BREWSTE He rises abruptly and starts to walk up and down the beac

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Good morning all.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Hi there!

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Bon jour, Madame. MISS BREWSTER notices POIROT's spoiled shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: What have you been up to Monsieur Poirot. Been trying to walk on the water?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I leave that performance to our Saviour, Madame. My own miracles, if such they can be described, come more from the exercise of the little grey cells, She laughs. And you Madame, - have you had your swim this morning?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Oh yes I had one about ten o'clock. In fact I was lucky to survive. Somebody chucked a bottle out of one of the hotel windows, and nearly brained me.  40 46 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: What a dangerous thing to do. Odell do you remember the Angelsturmer kid who got concussion right there in Mid town Manhattan, from a can of tooth- paste falling on his head?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Are you sure it wasn't toilet cleanser, dear. I had the distinct impression that that little Dutch girl on the can came into it somewhere ...

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: (firmly) Toothpaste!

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Concussion you say, from a tooth- paste tin? That does seem rather difficult to believe.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: It fell from a forty fifth floor window! MRS GARDENER chuckles to herself. A silence falls. They a watch PATRICK REDFERN impatiently pacing the beach and tu his head continually towards the direction of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Where's Mrs Marshall this morning? POIROT shrugs elaborately.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: I haven't seen her, But Mr Redfern sure looks mighty put out.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Yes he does, but it's Captain Marshall I really feel sorry for. He's such & quiet man - always so composed, but I'll bet he's actually seething inside. The CAMERA joins PATRICK REDFERN, now some distance away the group of MR and MRS GARDENER, MISS BREWSTER and HERCU POIROT. He saunters around aiming vicious swipes at limpe and crabs, with a piece of driftwood he has picked up. Occasionally he looks up in the direction of the hotel, t falls again to abusing the marine creatures. Back in the group, Miss Brewster gets to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Well I'm going for my row.  46 47 41 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: As for me I shail return to the hotel to change my shoes. It is not agreeable to be seen in this condition. POIROT bows to the company and trudges away in the direct of the hotel holding his wet shoes delicately in his hand MISS BREWSTER walks along the beach in the direction of t harbour. In doing this she has to pass PATRICK REDFERN.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Are you taking your boat out?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Mind if I join you.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Delighted.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Let's row right round the Island.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Have we got the time? She consults her watch. Oh yes. It's not eleven thirty yet. Come on. They walk in the direction of the harbour.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HARBOUR AND SEA MORNING
dialogues.text: The boat emerges from the harbour with PATRICK REDFERN ro with strong powerful strokes. MISS BREWSTER in the stern regards him with approval. The boat turns to the North ou of the harbour so that the Island is on its right hand si and the open sea on its left.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Good. Let's see how long you can keep that up for ... She waves to MR and MRS GARDENER as they pass the spot on beach where they are sitting. They wave pack. Then the bo passes round the point and they are lost to sight. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  48 49 42

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SEA/LIGHTHOUSE LEDGE MORNING
dialogues.text: PATRICK REDFERN rows the boat past Lighthouse Ledge. He scans the shoreline anxiously. The boat's progress slows.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Here come on, buck up! You're slacking! PATRICK REDFERN flashes her a charming smile.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: To be sure they'd have had you in charge of the galleys in the old days. He digs the oars in and the boat shoots forward. SLOW MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat rounds the next point, and Blood Bay comes into view. Distinctly we hear a chapel bell ringing twelve o'clock. It is quite a small cove facing North West, and the beach above the water line is shadowed by a huge overhanging cliff. A float is drawn up on the peach. A figure of a woman lies sprawled out on the sand, in the shaded part. WE ZOOM IN TO A CLOSE UP to see that her face is covered by a large screen cardboard Chinese hat f under which a long red curl escapes. Bronzed limbs protru from a white bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Hullo. Who's that in Blood Bay?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (sourly) Lucretia Borgia.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: You know it's Arlena Marshall as well as I do. You've been looking for her all morning.  49 50 43 Continued He grins sheepishly and alters course inshore.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: What are you doing? We don't want to land here.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Oh be a sport. It'll only be for a minute. PATRICK REDFERN jumps out and runs up the beach, waving a shouting. +

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Arlena! ... Arlena ... Hi there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HIGH ANGLED SHOT of Blood Bay as PATRICK REDFERN runs u the beach waving.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Hi there Arlena ... He reaches the figure and kneels down beside it. Hey, wake up! WE CUT INTO A CLOSE UP to see the bronzed limbs, the whit bathing suit, the red hair curling out from under the bri of the green Chinese hat. In the background we see MISS BREWSTER still in the boat. PATRICK REDFERN touches one o the bronzed arms then pulls his hand away as if stung. Fr MISS BREWSTER's point of view we see him lift the hat off face.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (shouting) My God!

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: She's dead .., She's been murdered ... strangled. He drops the hat back to cover the face and runs back dow the beach to MISS BREWSTER, still sitting in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Are you sure?  44 50 Continued PATRICK REDFERN nods his head dumbly.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: How horrible!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Who could have done this to Arlena? ... It's just not possible. My God, if I get my hands on the fiend who did this... MISS BREWSTER looks uneasily around her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: You don't suppose he's still hanging about do you?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (grimly) I hope so...

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: We must get the Police ... Perhaps one of us ought to stay with the body.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'11 stay. MISS BREWSTER sighs with relief.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Ob thank you. I'll be as quick as I can. I'll go in the boat ... Can't face that ladder. She points to an iron ladder which is clamped to the clif side, and which leads to the top. CUT BACK TO A HIGH ANGLED SHOT to see MISS BREWSTER row o round the point. 51 INT. DAPHNE‘CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY In her chaotic office in the hotel DAPHNE CASTLE is phoni the mainland, In the doorway hover POIROT and MISS BREWST DAPHNE (on phone) Listen Zoggy, sorry to use the private number - I know Queenie is a jealous cat and makes life hell for you - but we've had a murder ... yes a murder!  52 53 54 55 45

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRIVATE SITTING ROOM ROYAL PALACE TIRANE DAY
dialogues.text: KING ZOG flamboyantly dressed in crested smoking jacket paces his private sitting room as he holds the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: KING Z0G
dialogues.text: My dear Daphne, I simply can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DAPHNE CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Why not for heaven's sake? You have one every ten minutes in Tirane. It's Arlena Stuart - you know - the musical comedy star, Didn't you ever see Sunshine Strippers? She was quite appalling, but the music was jolly. (sings) Sunshine Strippers soaking up the sun. Sunshine Strippers having lots of fun ...

dialogues.speaker: KING Z0G, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Please Daphne will you concentrate on the murder!

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Well she's been strangled. Apparently they just found her on the beach wearing a hideous green hat.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRIVATE SITTING ROOM ROYAL PALACE TIRANE DAY
dialogues.text: KING ZOG on the phone,

dialogues.speaker: KING ZOG
dialogues.text: Never mind the hat. Who killed her?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Does it matter - everyone loathed her.

dialogues.speaker: KING Z0G
dialogues.text: Of course it matters. I'11 send an Inspector of Police.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DAPHNE CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE on the phone.  46 55 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: No, don't do that. I've got the best detective in the world here already - Hercule Poirot. Even you must have heard of him. She flashes a smile at POIROT, who preens himself, before turning back to the phone and lowering her voice.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) He's a finnicky little bugger, but a simply colossal brain. (normal voice) He says he must have a doctor to establish time of death and all that. Have you got one you can spare?

dialogues.speaker: KING Z0G, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes. I'll send one, and a policeman. This must be official.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Please Zoggy, can't you keep it quiet? You know how peculiar people are about a spot of murder. The scandal will zap my hotel, and I'm sure Monsieur Poirot will solve it in a jiffy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRIVATE SITTING ROOM KING ZOG'S PALACE TIRANE DAY
dialogues.text: KING ZOG on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: KING ZOG
dialogues.text: Alright Daphne, for old time's sake, and against my better judgement, I'll give you forty eight hours. After that it must be official.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You are a darling.

dialogues.speaker: KING ZOG
dialogues.text: Another thing - I've got a Colonel Race visiting me here. I understand he's an old friend of Poirot's - they worked together recently in Egypt when that American chewing gum heiress was murdered on the Nile. I'll send him too, with anoff the record police sergeant, who speaks a bit of English.  57 58 47

dialogues.speaker: INT. DAPHNE CASTLE'S OFFICE IN THE HOTEL DAY
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, you are without doubt the spiffiest chum any gal could have. ‘Bye. She hangs up and turns to face POIROT and MISS BREWSTER, winking and making a conspiratorial gesture.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: It's all fixed!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLOOD BAY AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A CLOSE UP as the green Chinese hat is removed. ARLENA MARSHALL's distorted, dead face, stares up at us in brigh sunlight. The tongue protrudes and the eyes bulge. We PULL BACK to see the middle-aged, wiry, Albanian Police Surgeon DR MUSA, kneeling down examining her. COLONEL RAC Stands nearby, with an overweight Albanian Sergeant of Police in a scruffy uniform. Also present are PATRICK REDFERN and MISS BREWSTER.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Well doctor what do you make of it?

dialogues.speaker: DR MUSA
dialogues.text: She was ... He demonstrates strangulation by putting his own hands round his throat, putting his tongue out, and making a hideous choking noise.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Strangled?

dialogues.speaker: DR MUSA
dialogues.text: Yes strangled - by big, big hands. He flexes his hands dramatically,

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: What about the time of death?

dialogues.speaker: DR MUSA
dialogues.text: Three four hours dead, no more.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (to Sergeant) What time is it now?  48 58 Continued

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Time to. eat.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: The hour. Not the state of your stomach, The SERGEANT holds up three fingers.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Three o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: {to Redfern) When did you find her?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: About noon.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: It was precisely twelve o'clock when we came in here. I heard the bell on the Fishermen's chapel round the corner in Bible Bay, strike the hour.

dialogues.speaker: DR MUSA
dialogues.text: Good. Strangled between 11 and 12.

dialogues.speaker: O.K.
dialogues.text: ‘ He acts it out as before.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Most helpful. We'll send the body over to the mainland for the post mortem.

dialogues.speaker: DR MUSA
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Chop her up later. Goodbye. DR MUSA packs up his bag and with a formal bow, trudges o the sand towards the ladder and starts to climb up it.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Competent enough I daresay, but needs to brush up his bedside manner. (to Sergeant) Outline the position.of the body will you before it is removed.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Outline? RACE demonstrates with a stick.  58 59 49 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Like this.

dialogues.speaker: O.K.
dialogues.text: He starts work to outline the corpse as the CAMERA MOVES to an EXTREME CLOSE UP of its distorted features.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE RESIDENTS' LOUNGE HOTEL AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: RACE and POIROT are alone in the lounge.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: It is absolutely extraordinary finding you here Poirot. Wherever there's a juicy murder you seem to pop up like a jack rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I could say the same thing about you cher Colonel. If it is not too indiscreet of me may I enquire what you were doing visiting le roi Zog?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Dope running if you must know. There's a@ chap I've been after for years - uses a dozen aliases. He's moving the stuff up now from Turkey through the Balkans, and I've had a strong tip off he's round here at the moment. Still we'd better get on with this lot. It looks a very tricky business.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It is true that most people here would have murdered Madame Marshall avec grande plaisir but do not worry mon vieux. .The order and method of Hercule Poirot will triumph in the end. Now I suppose you will want to start by finding out who was the last person to see Madame Marshall alive?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Yes. I have always found they are the most suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Parbleu! In this case I think you will find that that person was me.  50 59 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: What !!

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais oui. Apart of course from the murderer. I helped her push her float out from Booty Beach at about ten forty this morning. She asked me not to tell anyone where she was going.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: POTROT
dialogues.text: She said she wanted to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: From what I hear, that was not a desire she expressed too frequently.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: My own opinion exactly. But who then, did she go to meet? RACE shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: At any event she would have arrived there shortly after eleven o'clock - the earliest time Dr Musa gave for her death,

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Exactement. .

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: So we can assume that she was murdered there, and not transported there after she was killed - which I suppose limits our suspects to those people on the Island, since anyone coming over from the mainland would have been seen.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And no one was?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Not so far as we have been able to find out.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Then let us begin with the husband, if for no other reason than that matrimonial causes provide the motive for the majority of female murders.  60 51

dialogues.speaker: INT. KENNETH MARSHALL'S BEDROOM AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Present in Kenneth Marshall's room are the CAPTAIN himsel POIROT and RACE. He sits in an armchair facing RACE, whil POIROT wanders round the room. picking up and putting dow objects. Standing against one of the walls is a desk with papers and a typewriter on it.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: So that is why we thought we would start our enquiries with you, Capitaine Marshall. A callous reason, but sensible, I'm sure you'll agree. After all, you have a very good, very old fashioned motive - jealously.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: You think that,

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Come, sir. It is a matter of common knowledge here that your wife and Mr Redfern were on terms of the greatest intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I do not listen to tittle tattle, Inspector. My wife is dead and cannot defend herself.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I'm not asking her to defend herself. If I'm asking anybody, I'm asking you. Were you jealous of her?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Many men have admired my wife Colonel. If I was the type of man who would kill for jealously, I would have killed her years ago.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It has been my experience that all men are the type of men who would kill for jealousy. You, Monsieur must be tout a fait exceptionnel. Mes felicitations. KENNETH MARSHALL shrugs with irritation and turns away fr POIROT.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (to Race) Have you any questions to ask me?  52 60 Continued He rises letters. He hands his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I would like an account of your move-- ments this morning, please, between eleven and twelve o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It's quite simple. I was in here typing until I changed to play tennis a few minutes after twelve o'clock. and crosses to the desk, from which he picks up three

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Here they are, If you put one of your men to type them, you will find he won't be able to do them in much under an hour ... (to himself) Where is that damned pipe? the letters to RACE, and then pats his pockets for Finding them empty he goes to search for it is a random manner amongst his tobacco pouch, matches and clea on the desk. He fails to find it, and gives up.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
