dialogues.text: What is there to show that they could not have been typed at some other time - say last night for example?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Today is the twenty-fifth. As you will see, these letters are postdated in answer to this one from my stockbroker, posted in London, the twenty-third, and arriving here on this morning's post at about ten thirty. As I was down on Booty Beach with you Monsieur Poirot at a little after ten forty five, you will see clearly that I must have typed them when I said I did.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It would appear so.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Well, if you're still not satisfied, why not ask the chambermaid if she heard the machine going. She was moving about the corridor some of the time, doing out other rooms.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Thank you Captain Marshall. We'll do that. Now can you tell us what you did after you'd finished typing?  60 61 Continued

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: As I eaid I went to play tennis. The date was for twelve fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Whom did you play with?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle, Mr Gardener, and Mrs Redfern.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And was everyone there on time?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: No. I was the first to arrive. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 KENNETH MARSHALL is taking the tennis balls out of their and knocking them over the net. DAPHNE CASTLE arrives.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Hullo ... jolly good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Hullo Ken. She takes off her sweater.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -,... I think I was there dead on time. Then Mrs Castle joined me.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did she seem quite normal?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you've seen anything of Arlena this morning have you? I haven't seen her since breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Quite normal? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I saw her on a float earlier this morning. I think she's up the North end of the Island somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Was she with anyone?  61 54 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: No. She was alone. Though she was probably heading for some sleazy rendezvous with her leprechaun lover? Oh Ken, it's not right for you to let her torture you this way.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I mean did she look agitated, or flushed, or excited in any way?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Don't be silly Daphne. You do exagger- ate everything so. Arlena may be a bit of a flirt but she knows where to draw the line.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. She looked her usual soigne self.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: The only line Arlena's drawn is under a column of figures.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Drop it will you ... Here's Gardener. MR GARDENER arrives and DAPHNE CASTLE and KENNETH MARSHAL move to take up position on one side of the net.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Hi there!

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Hullo. Had a good morning?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Sure. Great.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And who was the next to arrive?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr Gardener. He must have been about five or six minutes late.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: How about a knock up?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: (mock scandalized) A knock up!  61 62 55 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Yes. You know ~ a spot of practice till Mrs Redfern comes.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Oh. You should know that in my country, a knock up means something totally different.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Oh really? Surely you can't mean jolly rogering. They laugh and start to play.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And how did Mr Gardener look?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: As he always does - like a sober, up- right, henpecked New York attorney.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: _I see. Tell me, how much later was it before Mrs Redfern arrived? A QUICK MIX to indicate the passing of time. CHRISTINE RE hurries onto the court.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late ... I was sketching over at Cutlass Cove and I lost track of the time.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Come and play with me.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I don't know, Seven or eight minutes. She said she'd been over at Cutlass Cove and forgotten the time. CHRISTINE REDFERN walks over to join MR GARDENER. MIX THROUGH to the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KENNETH MARSHALL'S BEDROOM AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: POIROT, RACE and KENNETH MARSHALL are grouped as they wer at the end of Scene 60.  62 Continued 56

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: And to save you the question, she did not look agitated flushed or excited in any way, though of course she had been hurrying.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Just two things, Monsieur. Firstly, will these letters show your investments to have been profitable?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: No. I'm afraid they will reveal I have sustained some substantial losses recently.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Secondly, is it true that your wife had quite a lot of money of her own?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: She inherited some money recently - yes.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Did she leave a will?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yes. Alright, I succeed to her property, but I didn't kill her, if that's what you think. (raised voice) I did not kill her! Understand! The connecting door between his and his daughter's bedroo opens, and LINDA MARSHALL comes rushing in.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Oh daddy, daddy! ... What are they doing to you?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It's alright, my darling. It's just a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: But you didn't kill Arlena. I know you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should have a little talk, Linda. Is that your room?  62 63 64 57 Continued She nods her head.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Good. Well why don't we go in there, and leave your father to himself for awhile. RACE rises and leads the way next door. POIROT and LINDA MARSHALL follows.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL'S BEDROOM AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: RACE stands up. POIROT sits in a rocking chair. LINDA MAR sits on the end of her bed.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Sorry to have to put you through this, Linda, but we have to find out every- thing that might be useful, and that means talking to everyone - understand? LINDA MARSHALL joins her large, bony hands together, and twists them nervously.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Good. Then just tell us what you did this morning, after you got up.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I went for an early bathe before break- fast, then I went to Cutlass Cove with Mrs Redfern.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And what time did you go?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: We had a date to meet in the hall at ten thirty. I thought I was going to be late, but it was alright. I asked Daphne to come with us, but she was busy ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL MORNING
dialogues.text: A REVERSE CAMERA ANGLE to scene 45, favouring the three l DAPHNE CASTLE, CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL. In the background HERCULE POIROT sits at his table on the te  64 65 66 67 58 Continued drinking his coffee. DAPHNE CASTLE parts from the other t to go up the path Westwards towards Lighthouse Ledge. CHR REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL strike out North-Eastwards tow Cutlass Cove. WE CUT TO A HIGH SHOT to see the women diverging, and, mo clearly, the topography of the Island, They wave to each before disappearing out of each other's sight.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And how long did it take you to get there, do you think? MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PATH LEADING FROM THE HOTEL TO CUTLASS COVE MORNING
dialogues.text: LINDA MARSHALL and CHRISTINE REDFERN walk across the Isla towards Cutlass Cove. The angle favours LINDA MARSHALL an her eyeline.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh I don't know - ten minutes, a bit more maybe. We weren't in any partic- ular hurry. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOP OF CUTLASS COVE MORNING
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL arrive on top of Cut Cove, and start to descend the path to the beach. We see scene from LINDA MARSHALL's angle.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And what did you do when you got there? MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CUTLASS COVE MORNING, (10.45 A.M.)
dialogues.text: Again the angle favours LINDA MARSHALL. CHRISTINE REDFERN up her easel in the shade provided by the overhanging cli and starts to sketch the cliffs. She does not remove her pyjamas. LINDA MARSHALL takes off her beach wrap and watc oils herself, and lies down in the sun to sunbathe. The C position is on the sea side, South East of Linda Marshall shooting North West.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I sunbathed and Mrs Redfern, sat in the shade sketching. She doesn't like the sun you know. She gets blisters.  67 68 59 Continued

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: (sketching) Move over, Augustus John.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Oh isn't he the one who's always driving his wife crazy, by having the most tre- mendous affairs with all his pupils ... Oops, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: It's alright. She smiles bravely.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then what happened? The CAMERA PANS to a CLOSE UP of the shadow of the cliff the beach. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The angle favours LINDA MARSHALL and her eyeline. The sun has moved over to the West, and the shadow stretc deeper away from CHRISTINE REDFERN towards the sea. As th shadow touches her, LINDA MARSHALL rises.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Well nothing much. We jawed away, and the time simply flew by ...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: What time is it? LINDA MARSHALL looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Twelve o'clock. CHRISTINE REDFERN gets up and puts away her sketch things quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Lord I must fly. I'm playing tennis at twelve fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: O.K. 1'11 have a swim before I come back. LINDA MARSHALL starts to run down towards the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 60 Continued

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Don't forget your bathing cap. LINDA MARSHALL retraces her steps, puts on her bathing ca and runs off down to the sea.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: See you later. The CAMERA travels down to the sea with LINDA MARSHALL.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . At any rate Mrs Redfern suddenly asked me the time, and I told her, and she had to rush off back to the hotel to change for tennis, and I went in for a swim. I remember I was half way down the beach when Mrs Red- fern called after me I had forgotten my bathing cap, so I had to come back and put it on. What a bore! From the sea, we look back up the beach to see CHRISTINE REDFERN moving quickly up the path to the cliff top. From top she waves to LINDA MARSHALL, who waves back.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And what time was it when all that happened? MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LINDA MARSHALL'S BEDROOM AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: RACE, POIROT and LINDA MARSHALL are in the same positions they were before, at the end of Scene 63.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Twelve o'clock. She certainly cut it fine for her tennis date. POIROT moves over to look at her watch. It reads three th He takes out his own half hunter from his waistcoat pocke compares it. It too reads three thirty.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle did you love your step- mother?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: My father did, so I tried to for his sake.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: But it was not easy, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 Continued 61

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: She was not my mother.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And she came between your father and yourself?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: En effet ma petite, you hated her - that's the truth, n'est ce pas? She was always humiliating you in public. You wanted her out of your family. You could cheerfully have wished her dead!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Poirot!

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (suddenly hysterical) It's true!...I did... Many many times... Just like I'm sure Mrs Redfern did, be- cause her husband was in love with her ... She was always on at me, taunting me, making me look foolish and childish. She was so cruel ... so cruel ... POIROT stares at her, not moving, giving her time to coll herself. RACE makes to go and comfort her, but POIROT sto

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: But anyhow wishing someone dead, isn't the same thing as doing it, is it?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Chard) Non, Mademoiselle, it ts not at all the same. One is a pleasurable fantasy - the other takes strength and purpose. It takes the ability to contemplate calmly the bulging eyes, the blackening skin, the last gurgle of exhaled breath. LINDA MARSHALL suddenly gets up, and with a stifled cry r from the room.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Did you have to be so rough on her, Poirot? I mean she's only a kid.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (gently) Mon vieux, I did not suggest anything to her, that she herself has not already  69 70 62 Continued POIROT (Cont) thought of a hundred times and she does have an usually strong pair of hands for a girl of her age.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Alright, I'll accept that. What did you think about her father?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Le bon Capitaine would be more prudent to cultivate an air of | greater tristesse if he does not wish to be suspected of her death.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Perhaps you're right. Well I'li get the sergeant to work on the type- writer alibi - see if he can do them in under an hour - and then we should have a word with Valentino.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWIMMING POOL AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: in a series of quick cuts we watch PATRICK REDFERN execut ever higher and more elaborate dives into the .swimming p POIROT watches thoughtfully from a concealed place in the arborial surroundings. He is joined by RACE.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Very impressive stuff, eh Monsieur Poirot? He should be in training for the Berlin Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais oui. Those I should like to see. They say there is an American Negro - a man called Jesse Owens - who is absolument formidable!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: It's funny but he too doesn't look to me much like a man who has just lost his lady love.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You think he is celebrating? ... C'est possible. PATRICK REDFERN does a final dive, swims to the pool's ed and climbs out. POIROT and RACE move out from their cover to confront him.  63 70 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Monsieur Redfern. Colonel Race here is of the opinion that vous avez un coeur leger.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: And what might that mean?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: That you are gay — lighthearted.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Lighthearted! If I didn't do some- thing, I think I'd go off my chump. What's happened is so unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Not in my experience, monsieur. I find it quite believable.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (savagely) Obviously you are more accustomed to murder than I am, Monsieur Poirot. You have probably seen quite a few in your time, and have learnt how to behave.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Vraiment and they have also given me many opportunities of observing how suspects behave. And I can assure you that very few of them have been blithe. POIROT and PATRICK REDFERN glare at each other before the latter moves to put on his bathing robe, and sit down at poolside table.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Mr Redfern may I ask how long you had known Mrs Marshall?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: About three months. We met at a cocktail party in London.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And had you agreed to meet down here, or was it mere coincidence?  64 70 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: No, I must admit it was not coincidence. She asked me to come, and I suppose I couldn't resist. You see I was infatu- ated with her. I'd have done any mortal thing the asked.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You paint a very clear picture of her. She was the eternal Circe, n'est ce pas?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (rueful) She turned men into swine alright! You see deep down I know I love my wife.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Well mon vieux, that does rather establish a motive for the murder n'est ce pas?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: A motive - for me? Holy Mother of God why should I have wanted her dead? I was crazy about her.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: So you say. But it is possible she had become too importunate, and was making it impossible for you to return to the wife you loved. Many women have been killed in this world, for no other reason than that they became a nuisance.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: I assure you it wasn't like that at all. I could have taken off any time I wanted to. Anyway what are you saying? That it was me who killed her? You must know that couldn't possibly be the case. Wasn't I with yourself the whole time tili I went on with Miss Brewster and found her lying dead?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: So Monsieur, it is I who am to be your alibi?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Isn't it true? POIROT spreads his hands in a gesture of capitulation.

dialogues.speaker: -POIROT
dialogues.text: Helas - oui!  65 70 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well there you are then.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Eh bien. Whom do you think she had gone to meet at Blood Bay?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: I really haven't the faintest idea.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: How about your wife? She had a good motive for killing Madame Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: What!!

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Absolument. La Jalousie!!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: What nonsense. There's no violence in her. Besides how could she have done it? She'd never have been able to climb down that ladder to the beach - she's no head for that sort of thing at all. - And even if she could have, she was no match for Arlena. She'd have been the one to have been murdered. No, if it's jealousy you're after I'd have a go at Ken Marshall. He must be favourite. Now is that all?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: For the moment yes. But please hold your- self in readiness to reconstruct for us tomorrow morning your finding of Arlena Marshall's body, with Mademoiselle Brewster. PATRICK REDFERN walks away towards the hotel. Suddenly there is a cracking of twigs in the bushes behin where the two men are sitting. In a flash COLONEL RACE ha risen and parted them to discover DAPHNE CASTLE crouched in a position from where she has been able to overhear ev thing. She rises insouciantly and steps out, favouring bo men with a radiant smile.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: You're absolutely on the right track, Monsieur Poirot. Cherchez la temme! She's the one with the best motive. Captain Marshall simply isn't the type.”

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: So you have been h'eavesdropping, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Now don't be tiresome Monsieur Poirot. Everyone h'eavesdrops if they've got any sense. As a detective you must do it all the timn  70 7 66 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Madame, I assure you that Hercule Poirot has no need ...

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: And don't you believe all that guff about Arlena being the stronger..Women fight like tigers when they're losing their husbands - not that I've had too much experience of that sort of thing myself. I mean I tried everything to get rid of Johnnie - strychnine in the spuds ~ bolting to South America, but he clung on like a limpet. If the market crash in '29 hadn't given him a coronary, he'd be here now. Still it showed where his heart was.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Merci, madame. We Will heed your advice.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: You do that. She probably battered her with a bit of driftwood or something, and then finished her off with a little pressure on the carot artery, or whatever it's called. Everyone knows about that - all the crime novels are full of it. In fact an eleven year old child did something like that only the other day in Hungary - or was it Crete? ... Anyway I've got to see about dinner. Au revoir. They watch in silence as she walks away towards the hotel

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Do you think she was serious about putting strychnine in her husband's food? I mean if she's killed once ...

dialogues.speaker: POTROT
dialogues.text: ... She could have killed Madame Marshall? C'est possible. She certainly has the motive.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Really? What might that be?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) To become herself Madame Marshall. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

dialogues.speaker: THE GOLF COURSE THE FAIRWAY OF THE FIRST HOLE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN is attempting to play golf. Her appalli lunge at the ball sends it perilously between POIROT and as they come into sight over a rise. They both duck nervo  71 Continued

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: 67 REDFERN comes running across to them.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry. You're not hurt are you?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Don't worry. No harm done.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: I suppose I should have shouted fore or something, but I forgot. As a matter of fact I'm a complete duffer at this game. I only play to please Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Do not disturb yourself madame. The re- doubtable Colonel, and needless to say myself, have faced greater dangers in the course of our professional lives. He has learned le sang froid. I have learned the stiff lip. She smiles thinly. They walk

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Have you come to interview me?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Just a few questions. But please do not derange your game.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Perhaps you could tell us something about how you spent this morning? towards where the golf ball lies in deep rough.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well first thing this morning at about eight-thirty I went into Linda Marshall's room to fix up with her to go to Cutiass Cove. You see I wanted to do some sketching.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And she was up at that hour?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Oh yes. As a matter of fact she wasn't actually in her room, when I arrived. She came in a few minutes later. She'd been for a dip.  71 72 73 74 68 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: What time did you and Linda Marshall leave the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: About ten thirty.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And how long did it take you to walk to this cove?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: I don't know. Between ten minutes and B quarter of an hour. : MIX THROUGH TO next scene as CHRISTINE REDFERN takes a wi swing at the ball, missing it completely.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE PATH LEADING TO CUTLASS COVE MORNING
dialogues.text: The angle favours CHRISTINE REDFERN and her eyeline, CHRISTINE REDFERN is in front of LINDA MARSHALL by a coup of feet.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was an absolutely spiffing morning, so we just ambled along, chattering away like a couple of magpies. MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOP OF CUTLASS COVE MORNING
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN and LINDA MARSHALL arrive on top of Cut Cove and start to depcend the path to the beach. As indic we see the scene froth CHRISTINE REDFERN's angle.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: How did you spend your time at the Cove? MIX THROUGH TO next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CUTLASS COVE MORNING, (10.45 A.M.)
dialogues.text: Again the scene is observed from CHRISTINE REDFERN’s angl She sets up her easel in the shade provided by the overha eliff, and starts to sketch the cliffs. LINDA MARSHALL ta off her beach wrap and watch, oils herself, and lies down sunbathe. The CAMERA position is on the cliff side, North West of CHRISTINE REDFERN shooting South East towards the The dialogue is as in scene 67.  74 75 69 Continued

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I set up my easel in the shade and sketched some cliffs. Linda sunbathed.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0)
dialogues.text: And the two of you stayed like that? Neither of you moved?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's right. It was just so peaceful there.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And what time did you leave? The CAMERA PANS to a CLOSE UP of the shadow of the cliff beach. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has moved over to the West, and the shadow stretc deeper away from CHRISTINE REDFERN towards the sea. This, is seen from CHRISTINE REDFERN's angle. As the shadow tou her, LINDA MARSHALL rises and looks at her watch. CHRISTI REDFERN geis “pand puts away her sketch things quickly, a LINDA MARSHALL starts to run towards the sea. The dialogu as before.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was twelve o'clock. It had suddenly got quite late you see, and I had to hurry because I had a date to play tennis at twelve fifteen, and I had to change first. LINDA MARSHALL retraces her steps and puts on her bathing in response to CHRISTINE REDFERN's call.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You had your watch with you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: No. I asked Linda the time. LINDA MARSHALL runs off down to the sea. The CAMERA does not move, but stays with CHRISTINE REDFER she watches the girl rush into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Anyway I packed up my sketching things as quickly as I could, and went back to the hotel.  75 76 77 78 70 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And Mademoiselle Linda?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She went into the sea. CHRISTINE REDFERN hurries up the path to the cliff top, t CAMERA going with her, but looking out to sea where LINDA MARSHALL is bathing.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did she enter the water before you left the Cove?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN looks down and waves to LINDA MARSHALL the sea. She waves back.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh yes. 1 waved to her from the top of the cliff. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: OF THE HOTEL MIDDAY
dialogues.text: A montage of running shots ending with CHRISTINE REDFERN entering the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then I simply tore back to the hotel as fast as I could ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN, now in tennis clothes, is tying up the of her gym shoes. She unfastens her racquet from its pres and dashes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . and changed into my tennis things. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  79 80 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN hurries onto the tennis court, where KE MARSHALL and DAPHNE CASTLE are knocking up against MR GARDENER. She joins MR GARDENER. Dialogue as pefore.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (Y.O.)
dialogues.text: I then went to the court where I met the others.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Who were ...?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Captain Marshall, Mrs Castle, and Mr Gardener. I played with Mr Gardener. We had a couple of sets, and then ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: POIROT, RACE and CHRISTINE REDFERN have moved about forty from where they were at the end of scene 71. The golf bal in even thicker rough.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: ... we heard about Mrs Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Madame, I must 2sk you, were you very surprised at the manner of Madame Marshall's death?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well of course to be around when an actual murder is committed is so rare that of course it is surprising - sur- prising and shocking. But I suppose she was the kind of woman ...

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: To whom such a thing might happen? ... Yes. I find that very significant.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well I mean to say it's true. After all people like her are always mixed up with everything that's squalid and sordid - blackmail, jealousy, violence - every kind of crude emotion.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Why, Madame, did you mention the word blackmail?  80 Continued 72

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Er ... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Come, you were quite specific. To your knowledge was Madame Marshall being blackmailed? There is a tiny pause during which CHRISTINE REDFERN come a decision.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Yes, Monsieur Poirot. I'm afraid she was.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: What!!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to overhear, but I couldn't help it. It was yesterday afternoon. I was coming back from a walk along Mutiny Mile, and as I passed along the cliff above Blood Bay, I heard voices coming up from the beach. Arlena Marshall was saying "It's no use pressing me. I simply haven't got it to give you any more. As it is, my husband is getting suspicious". And another voice - a man's said "What rubbish. You'll pay up or I'll really make things hot for you".

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) You'll pay up, or I'll really make things hot for you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: That's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Parbleu. He must have been listening to too many blackmailers.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: (hotly) I'm sorry you think it's a cliché, Monsieur Poirot, but those were the words used.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Did you recognize his voice?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: No. He was keeping it low. But it was gruff and a bit hoarse.  80 81 73 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And that's all you heard?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm afraid I walked on rather quickly. It was a bit embarrassing you see.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Yes. I can quite see that. Thank you Mrs Redfern. We'll follow it up. She smiles weakly at them, and hacks furiously at her bal Turf flies through the air as POIROT and RACE beat a retr

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Now we are getting somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Well it does explain Mrs Marshall's seemingly inexplicable behaviour this morning doesn't it? Blood Bay is an ideal spot for a rendezvous with this fellow who's blackmailing her. It's accessible only by water or a ladder steep enough to deter most people and a great part of it is invisible from above.

dialogues.speaker: POLROT
dialogues.text: As you say it is an ideal spot for a rendezvous. But explain this to me, mon cher. Why is it not the pitiless and urgent blackmailer who lies dead, but his victim? Is this not indeed killing l'oie qui depose les oeufs d'ors? RACE regards POIROT with surprise. He is obviously impres by Poirot's point. The CAMERA PULLS UP and away. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TERRACE OUTSIDE THE HOTEL AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The ALBANIAN SERGEANT sits at a table with a typewriter i front of him. Gamely he bangs away at the keyboard typing Mr Marshall's letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 74 Continued

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (reading, laboriously to himself) Current difficulties would be solved by investing in Mr Stavisky's companies. Their high yields make a very attractive proposition ... He sighs elaborately and continues. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CROQUET LAWN AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: MR and MRS GARDENER are playing croquet. Once again, from concealed position, POIROT and RACE stand watching. MRS GARDENER whacks her husband's ball so that it goes scuddi away into the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Now, Odell I get another turn for hitting you. She takes another shot and goes through a hoop. And I get another one for going through the hoop. She knocks her ball towards the next hoop. MR GARDENER tr off to retrieve his ball. He plays a good shot which puts back near his wife's ball. She whacks it away in another direction, but by doing so puts her own out of position, through the hoop. As her husband's back is turned while h goes to retrieve his own ball, she quite blatantly cheats moving her ball so that she can easily manoeuvre it throu hoop. She does this then whacks it joyfully up towards th finishing post. MR GARDENER looks on in a defeated way, f the bushes where his ball is.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I thought we agreed one had to go through the hoop at the top again, before finishing dear.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: You are quite in error Odell. We agreed no such thing. She hits the finishing post with her ball and wins the ga Come along, I'll give you one more game.  82 75 Continued POIROT and RACE emerge from their place of concealment an approach MRS GARDENER. Her husband has quite a long walk back from the bushes to join them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Hullo there Monsieur Poirot. How goes the investigation?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It marches Madame. It marches. Let me introduce you to my colleague Colonel Race - Mr and Mrs Gardener. RACE smiles charmingly.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: My, you British bobbies are all so charming and sympathetic. I remember I lost a bracelet once at the Savoy - we thought it had been stolen - and a delightful young officer came and found it in a vase of roses where it must have fallen from my wrist when I was arranging them. I thought he'd have been mad as hell wasting his time and all. But not a bit of it.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: It wasn't a vase of roses, honey. It was a jardiniere in the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: It was a vase of roses, Odell. Red, long stemmed roses that Hattie Hymenheimer had sent to us. Surely you remember how she and Betty Bernlumbenwitz had sobbed all the way through Carole Lombard in “Lady By Choice" - Men who loved her grew sadder but wiser.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: My recollection is that they brought us Arum Lilies, and that it was Joan Bennett in "While Paris Sleeps", they sobbed through. Don't you remember - While Paris Sleeps, Lovers, Wantons and Wastrels are Awake!

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: For the last time, Odell, it was a god- damned vase of red roses and...  -~ 82 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Mrs Gardener. I'm sorry to interrupt you, but could you give me your attention please.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: What? ... Why yes of course.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I would like an account of your movements between eleven and twelve o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Well now, let me see. Odell and I were on Booty Beach the whole time I guess, weren't we Monsieur Poirot. You remember! You were there.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Alas Madame the statement is not quite true. I took my departure from the beach a little before half past eleven, as did Mademoiselle Brewster and Monsieur Redfern. That left the two of you alone. MRS GARDENER laughs shrilly and exaggeratedly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Gee, I guess it does. Still, you can't really think that Odell and I had anything to do with the death of that unfortunate woman, Monsieur Poirot, now can you?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: We have to investigate everyone here madam, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: But neither Odell nor I would hurt a fly.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: We are not talking about les mouches, Madame. Had either of you met Madame Marshall before you came here?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: (together) No. Never.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: (together) Yes. As a matter of fact we had. MRS GARDENER looks daggers at her husband.  82 Continued 77

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: There seems to be a slight difference of opinion here.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Well, to tell the truth we invested in a Musical Comedy she did in the States, last year. We met her then.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Was it a successful show?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Hell, no. But it had a kind of appropriate name - Gold Diggers of 1934. You see it could have been successful but she left it after a few weeks to go off with some oleo margarine King, and it folded.

dialogues.speaker: RACE -
dialogues.text: As a result of which you lost your money?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I'll say we did.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: May I ask how much money you lost?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Sixty thousand clams. RACE whistles.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And so you bore Madame Marshall a grudge?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Well wouldn't you have? But not enough to bump her off. That's crazy talk.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I hope for your sake it is Madame. For you see you would have had all the time in the world to go to Blood Bay between eleven thirty and twelve o'clock and er ... bump her off. Am I not right?

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: What utter nonsense. I was with Odell on the beach during that time. Wasn't I? MR GARDENER nods unhappily.  82 83 84 78 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Did you not go to play tennis? Monsieur Marshall and Madame Redfern have said you did.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Er ... well yes, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: What time was that sir?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: The date was for twelve fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: But you had to change first, surely?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Er yes, that's true. I guess I left the beach about twenty of ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the path between Booty Bay and the Hotel, MR GARDENER examining some bizarre rock formations. He straightens up and walks on towards the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... There are some curious rock formations on the path back to the hotel which I wanted to examine at leisure.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I think it was a little later than that Odell. About ten minutes later, at least.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No, dear, I don't think so. The time was about twenty of twelve, I'm pretty sure.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did you see anybody on your way back to the hotel? MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR GARDENER is changing for tennis. His clothes are old- fashioned even for the period, and his racquet is ancient  84 85 86 87 79 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No sir. I saw no one either on the path or in the hotel. I went straight to my room and changed. MR GARDENER looks out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the exterior of the hotel from MR GARDENER's point view in his first floor bedroom. We see CHRISTINE REDFERN hurrying off the path which leads to Cutlass Cove, and in the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: However while I was changing, I did see from my window Mrs Redfern hurry into the hotel from the direction of Cutlass Cove.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What sort of time would that have been? MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR GARDENER moves away from the window, consults his watc picks up his racquet which he removes from its press.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 1 reckon about ten after twelve, or a little later. He leaves the room. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR GARDENER arrives at the tennis court, and DAPHNE CASTL and KENNETH MARSHALL who are already there, move to take position on one side of the net.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Who was there when you arrived?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Captain Marshall and Mrs Castle.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did you notice anything out of place about either of them?  87 88 80 Continued

dialogues.speaker: . MR GARDENER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Out of place?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: How shall I put it - a tautness of manner, an unnatural excitement.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Both of them were animated. But I wouldn't Say unnaturally so.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Could you tell me how much later than you was Mrs Redfern in arriving at the court. A QUICK MIX to indicate the passage of time. CHRISTINE RE hurries onto the court, and joins MR GARDENER.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well now let me see. I was about five minutes late, and she was approximately ten minutes or so after me. I'd say it was around twelve thirty when she got there. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CROQUET LAWN AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: POIROT, RACE and MR and MRS GARDENER stand on the croquet as they were at the end of scene 82.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And that's all you can tell us?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so. It wasn't till after the game that we heard of the tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Au revoir then, Madame, Monsieur. Enjoy passing through the little hoops. He gives them a little bow, and he and RACE walk off in t direction of the harbour, leaving the GARDENERS alone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: (furious) So you had to tell them about all that money we lost. eh? That wasn't very smart of you, Odell. Not very smart at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 89 90 81 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, dear. It just sort of slipped out.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Slipped out? ... It sort of gushed out, like Goddamned Niagara Falls. And why did you have to go and tell them you left the beach at twenty of twelve?

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: Well I didn't want to lie now honey did I? They always find these things out you know, .

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Baloney! Don't you realise that neither of us has got an alibi now? You are a bloody tool, Odell. Sometimes you make me so mad I could ... Oh hell! She strikes off her croquet ball for a new game. The CAME TRACKS into a CLOSE UP of her large hands gripping the to the mallet as if strangling it. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HARBOUR AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: MISS BREWSTER's large hands grasp the oars of a row boat. PULL BACK to see her taking them out of their rowlocks, p them inboard, and leaping out of the boat onto the harbou where she makes it fast to a bollard. Sitting on two othe bollards are POIROT and RACE. As MISS BREWSTER gets back boat to tidy it and bale out surplus water they rise and over to her.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle ,I would like to hear some more about the incident of the bottle which nearly hit you this morning.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Oh that! Well, it must have been about 10.15 and I was taking a dip on the hotel beach ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS BREWSTER, attired in an antediluvian bathing costume swimming energetically. Suddenly a glass bottle comes hur  90 91 82 Continued down out of the sky, and lands with a great splash right to her. It filis with water and sinks. MISS BREWSTER look up angrily at the hotel windows but is unable to discover which one it has been thrown, because the sun is in her e

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ... when suddenly this bottle came whizzing out of the blue and smacked down in the water next to me.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (to herself, sotto voce) Bloody maniac!

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did you happen to notice what kind of a bottle it was, or from what window it was thrown?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. It sank too quickly for that, and when I looked up at the hotel, I couldn't see much because the sun was in my eyes. MISS BREWSTER swims ashore and starts to pick her way ove rocks towards the hotel's outside staircase.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tres curieux. And now, madame, I should like to know what you did between finish- ing your bathe and coming down to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh I don't know ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MISS BREWSTER'S BEDROOM MORNING
dialogues.text: MISS BREWSTER is doing some physical jerks in her room - breathing, knee bends, sit ups etc.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: 1 changed out of my wet costume, did a few physical jerks, read the newspaper. Why? Is it important?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Parbleu. It is of the very greatest importance! You must see that during this time it would have been quite possible for you to have gone. over to  91 92 83 Continued POIROT (Cont V.0.) Blood Bay, waited for Madame Marshall to arrive there shortly after eleven o'clock, killed her, and then to have returned in time to join us at about eleven twenty on Booty Beach. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HARBOUR AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: MISS BREWSTER, POIROT and RACE are as they were at the en scene 89. .

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: D'ye mean climb up and down that cliff ladder? You must be loopy if you think I could do that, with my head for heights.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we have only your word for that unfortunate malady, Mademoiselle.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Well, why should I want to? Just answer me that,

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Non. You answer me that s'il vous plait.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I had no reason. -

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: But that is not.the complete truth. You have already told me that you were em- ployed as Arlena Marshall's secretary for over five years, and that she gave you nothing ~- no references, no help. In fact she used every device in her power to prevent you telling the truth about her. What I wonder could you have meant by that? _ MISS BREWSTER climbs out of the boat onto the jetty to co POIROT.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Monsieur Poirot, I have my skills as a secretary, but as you may have noticed, I am not a pretty girl from Pitman's College who finds it easy to get a job anywhere at three or four pounds the week. So after I was dismissed I wrote an account of my life with Mrs Marshall,  92 Continued 84 MISS BREWSTER (Cont) hoping to serialise it in the tabloid press. I called it The Secret Life of Arlena Stuart - by her Personal Secretary, with the subtitle The Actress Who Lived Up To The Reputation She Couldn't Live Down! Believe it or not, I got immediate and generous offers to publish, both here and in America, but she stopped me.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: How Mademoiselle?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Well you see, without realising it I had signed a contract of employment, one clause of which prevented me from publishing any- thing about my former employer whilst ... (she pauses)

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Whilst ...?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (reluctantly ) Whilst she was alive.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And now that she is dead, Mademoiselle, you can go ahead - n'est ce pas? She shoots him a terrified glance.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Well I suppose put like that, yes ... but [ assure you I don't know anything about her death. Nothing at all. You must believe that Monsieur Poirot ... you must!

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Calm yourself, mademoiselle. You are not the only person here with a motive for choking Madame Marshall to death. Good afternoon. He gives her his little bow. She gives him another scared and then blunders away up the jetty.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Did you see her hands Poirot? They were absolutely enormous.  92 93 85 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Vraiment cher Colonel. Never have I seen so many women in one place with hands that Jim Braddock himself would like to own, It is most strange.

dialogues.speaker: EXT.. HOTEL TERRACE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A large pair of hands pound a typewriter. We PULL BACK to see the ALBANIAN SERGEANT still hard at work on Kenneth Marshall's letters. DAPHNE CASTLE stands looking over his shoulder reading what he has typed. POIROT and RACE appear and walk across the terrace toward them.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Well how's it going Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Is taking a long time - much more than one hour to do this.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Hullo, What's the poor man trying to do - preak the Albanian speed typing record? She picks up a couple of letters at random and starts to read them. We notice that her hands also are large.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: He is trying to prove an alibi, madame.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Whose? Kenneth Marshalls? If his wife was wealthy he certainly needs one. poor love. Was she wealthy by the way?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It appears so, but why do you ask that?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well look at these letters. Spondulix wise he appears to be up shit creek with- out a paddle.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Pardon? Qu est ce que c'est cette Sheet Creek?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I think Mrs Castle means to imply that Captain Marshall-is in financial difficulties.  86 93 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais oui. That he has already told us.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Still Ken never cared about money. I only hope you're satisfied with his alibi.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Certainment we know these letters had.to have been typed between eleven and twelve o'clock this morning - the time of the murder.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: He also claims one of the maids who was cleaning the rooms must have heard the sound of the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well, there it is. Ken certainly isn't clever enough to use the old gramophone record trick - you know the one where the murderer records the sound of a type- writer, puts it on the gramophone, and nips out and bops his wife while everyone thinks he's still in his room. POIROT and RACE give her the kind of looks they would bes on a mentally deficient child.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And of course a gramophone does not actually type letters, madame.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: No more it does. Silly me. RACE sighs and gives his attention to the SERGEANT.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Well, you can pack it in now. The point's proved. Instead I think you should take a little exercise.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Exercise?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I would like you to time how long it takes to get from the spot at Blood Bay where the body was found, from various points on the island, running both ways.  “on 93 o 94 on 87 Continued The SERGEANT's worst fears have been realised.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Running sir?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Oui. Like the miraculous Jesse Owens.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I don't think that's at all a good idea. In this heat, you'll give the Poor man a heart attack, and we'll have two corpses on our hands. Besides I have all the timings you want.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: You have all the timings!

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Come I'11 show you. She leads them into the hotel, as the SERGEANT makes a pr ful gesture that she has what they want.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMALL CONSERVATORY AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Watched by RACE and POIROT, DAPHNE CASTLE lifts the tarpa off a bulky object standing in the centre of the conserva to reveal a scale model of the island, beautifully worked coloured plaster. It shows the bays, paths, harbour, ligh house, chapel and hotel, all named, with little flags sho the times to various places, sticking up all over it.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: There you are. An old chum of mine did it a couple of years ago, when he had a little trouble paying his bill. Be careful of it ~ it's worth its weight in caviar. We move into an ECU of the model as the two men bend to e it. RACE points to the flags.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And these times are walking times?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Slouching times, I'd have said. (pointing) I mean fifty minutes from the hotel to the point of the island! If you jogged all the way, you could do it in half the time.  88 94 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (tracing with his finger from marker to marker) Then let us do that. Half of fifty is twenty-five - so that's twenty-five minutes from the Hotel to the Point. Seven minutes to Cutlass Cove. Eight minutes to Bounty Beach. Ten minutes to Blood Bay. Seven minutes to Lighthouse Ledge. From the Ledge to the Bay five minutes. From the Beach to the Bay twelve minutes, and from the Bay to Cutlass Cove four minutes.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Astounding mental arithmetic cher Colonel! I stand amazed. Eh maintenant, I would like your Sergeant to prepare more little flags for us with the names of the hotel guests on them, to use with this superb model. It will greatly facilitate our enquiry.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I'11 get him on to it.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Monsieur Poirot, I don't wish to be seeming to teach my grandmother to suck eggs or anything but I've changed my mind about the murderer. You see I was reading a magazine story about a woman in Malaya who was drowned by a huge Moray Eel which darted out of a hole and dragged her to the ocean floor, its teeth buried in her throat. and that gave me a new theory - about the Brewster woman, - Did you know by the way she was Arlena's secretary for years and was fired? Well anyway she could have been lurking in the water off Blood Bay when she appeared on that float thing and could have leapt up and pulled her off it ...

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Helas Madame Marshall was not drowned, madame. Still less was she gnawed to death.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well I'1l tell you what. She could have ...

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mrs Castle, forgive me, but as a matter of routine I should like to know where you were yourself between eleven o'clock and twelve noon.  94 95 96 89 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Me? But surely you can't think...

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Please Mrs Castle, we have to check everyone.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Well, about ten thirty I went for a walk over to Lighthouse Ledge, and I sat down there to make some notes for my staff meeting at eleven thirty. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTHOUSE LEDGE DAY
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE is sitting on a bench under the lighthouse, making notes. In the sea below ARLENA MARSHALL paddles by her float in a Northerly direction.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did you see anybody?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact I saw Arlena Marshall. She paddled by on a float.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Moving towards Blood Bay?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes. *

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Towards her death?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I suppose so, It had nothing to do with me. About half an hour later I returned to the hotel for my meeting. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL CONSERVATORY AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: POIROT, RACE and DAPHNE CASTLE are as they were in scene

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Can anyone vouch for you?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Of course - practically the whole staff can, from after eleven thirty that is. You see once a week it is my custom to  90 96 Continued DAPHNE CASTLE (Cont) collect them all together to give them a kind of collective boot up the bum. It does them no end of good - particularly the Eyeties - keeps them up to snuff as my old papa used to say. POIROT traces her proposed journey on the model.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: But you could have followed Madame Marshall along the cliff top and have been waiting in Blood Bay to strangle her when she arrived just after 11 o'clock. You would have had plenty of time to have returned here for the meeting at eleven thirty n'est ce pas?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: What a simply spifflicatingly absurd thing to say Monsieur Poirot.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Is it? I have seen the way you look at Captaine Marshall, Madame, and it seems to me that both you and he share the same motive.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't follow your drift at all.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Vraiment? With Arlena out of the way you two would be free to marry.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Me kill for love? I must say it's very flattering of you to suggest it, but I'm afraid I'm far too much of a hardened old trollop for that; and as for Kenneth, he'd never do it in a million years. Why he wouldn't even contemplate divorce when he must have known about every second man she met was throwing a leg over her.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ah, but even the protector of lame ducks may change when he meets his childhood sweetheart again after seventeen years, and realises he is still in love with her. She looks very embarrassed.  96 97 91 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Monsieur Poirot you have the Frenchman's obsession with the crime passionel.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: That is not so madame, but if I had it, it would be a Belgian obsession.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: For my part, Mrs Castle, I should like to know what you did after the staff meeting was over.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I had a date to play tennis at twelve fifteen, so I got changed and breezed off to the court. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSAMUND DARNLEY comes into the tennis court. KENNETH MARSHALL is knocking the last of the tennis balls he has taken from their box, over the net. The dialogue is as be

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When I got there Kenneth Marshall had arrived but the others hadn't.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The others?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr Gardener and Mrs Redfern.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: How did Captain Marshall's manner strike you?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: E'm not sure I understand the question?

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I want to know whether he was quite normal in his behaviour that's all. You know - fully composed?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I've never known Ken Marshall when he's not been as fully composed as a Beethoven Symphony. MR GARDENER arrives and DAPHNE CASTLE and KENNETH MARSHAL move to take up position on one side of the net.  97 98 92 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Your answer is very amusing Madame, put this is a serious matter, and it is very important to us to know your impressions of the people you were playing tennis with. In other words do you consider that any of them could have committed murder in the previous hour?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I was flippant. In answer to your question everybody appeared to me to be perfectly normal. I don't believe any one of them could have just strangled somebody.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: RACE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I believe Mr Gardener was the next to arrive. How much behind you was he?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. Not long. Maybe three or four minutes. A QUICK MIX to indicate the passing of time. CHRISTINE RE hurries onto the court and walks over to join MR GARDENER

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mrs Redfern was quite a bit later. She couldn't have been on court much before half past twelve ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMALL CONSERVATORY AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: RACE, POIROT and DAPHNE CASTLE are positioned as they wer at the end of scene 96.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Who won the tennis by the way? DAPHNE CASTLE is as surprised by the question as RACE,

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: What? Oh they did. Mrs R can sure hit "the jolly old pill" as if she hated it. If you ask me those milk white arms could mince the triceps of a six hundred pound Sumo wrestler.
i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 93 Continued POIROT has walked round to peer down a telescope mounted on a tripod which is pointing out towards the harbour.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ah a sail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see through the telescope MR BLATT's sailing boat head towards the island.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I think it might be our gallant mariner Monsieur Blatt.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMALL CONSERVATORY AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: POIROT steps away from the telescope and turns to RACE.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I've been wondering where he's been all day. Let us go down and pipe him ashore. Au revoir Madame, POIROT and RACE head towards the foyer of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Of course I'd forgotten Mr Blatt. He's obviously playing a double role, with all those terrible jokes and everything. I wouldn't mind betting he's an old flame Arlene picked up years ago when she was playing Blackpool or Skegness or some other frightful sea side resort, and got her hooks into and reduced to penury. He meets her here by chance and vows vengeance ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOYER HOTEL AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: POIROT and RACE keep going determinedly across the foyer and out of the hotel pursued by DAPHNE CASTLE's wild surm

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: +.» He would find it quite easy to sail round the island and strangle her with one of those clever nautical knots ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMALL CONSERVATORY AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE watches POIROT and RACE go, her mouth dropp in astonishment at their failure to listen further to her theorising.  102 103 94 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: +s. &@ bowline, or a sheepshank, or whatever they're called ... Her voice trails off disconsolately.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HARBOUR EVENING
dialogues.text: The time is now seven o'clock, BILL THE BOATMAN is making Mr Blatt's yawl for him. As POIROT and RACE approach the men it becomes clear that he is telling a dirty story,

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: You see this old feller, all bent over goes into an Ice Cream Parlour and says to the soda jerk "Ice Cream Sundae please". He replies "Crushed nuts Grandad?", and the old bloke says "No lad. It's rheumatism", MR BLATT laughs loudly and walks up the jetty towards POI and RACE. Behind them BILL shakes his head in baffled incomprehension,

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Hullo Monsewer. Old Bill just told me about the murder. I would have to be out on my boat for the day, and miss all the fun, wouldn't I? What a swiz!

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: This is Colonel Race. Monsieur Blatt. I don't think you will discover that he finds it quite as hilarious as you do.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Well I didn't mean ...

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: You say you went out sailing this morning? At what time may 1 ask?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Oh, early. About ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Was anyone with you?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Not a soul. I was all on my little owneo.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: South West. The wind was right behind me.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You didn't happen to approach Blood Bay at any time during the morning, did you?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Is that where the dark deed was done? No. I didn't go within miles of the Place. As a matter of fact I haven't seen anyone all day.  103 Continued 95

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And that's all you can tell us?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: 'Fraid so. Not much use I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Have you any ideas who could have done it?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Well it's obvious, isn't it? Cherchez le hubby.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It may be so, yes. All we know for certain is that Madame Marshall had a secret rendez- vous with someone at Blood Bay this morning.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Well, that had to be Redfern. Though why pick a draughty cove for a bit of nooky beats me. Reminds me of the old one about the wife watching her old man coming out of the sea, and saying to her friend, "Fred goes all blue and stiff when he's been in the water - not that I worry about the colour." Once again MR BLATT cracks up laughing. POIROT regards hi quizzically; RACE coldly.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: It wasn't Mr Redfern. We know that for a fact. It was somebody else - a blackmailer for example. °

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: (blustering) A blackmailer ... Wotcher mean?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (heavily) We believe she was being blackmailed - by a man.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Well don't look at me. That's not my handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: How do you make your money Monsieur Blatt?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: It's all perfectly legit. I'm in what you might call Seaside Novelties - you know, tricks, puzzles, saucy hats and picture post cards.  103 104 96 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Quelle surprise!

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Listen, if it wasn't Redfern and it wasn't Marshall, I'll bet I know who it was. Has to be. She said she was going to do it. Don't you remember, you were with me on the beach, yesterday morning, when she ran past?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You mean Mademoiselle Linda? Vraiment. She did certainly threaten to kill her step- mother, But she's so young.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: There's no such thing, these days. You mark my words. She's the one. He taps the side of his nose with a vast confidential for finger. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ARLENA MARSHALL'S BEDROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: A CLOSE UP of a pile of frilly underwear. We PULL BACL to the maid GLADYS NORRACOTT sorting them out, and tidying t away. POIROT and RACE appear in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. GLADYS NORRACOTT jumps.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Oooooh. Lord, you startied me.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Is your name Gladys Norracott?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Yes that’s me. I were just putting away Some of Mrs Marshall's things. I must say her smalls weren't ‘arf frilly. POIROT's eyes gleam as he fingers the pile.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ah yes, the foamy cami-knickers, swirling, half seen beneath the dramatically severe lines of the day suits. Extraordinaire!  104 97 Continued GLADYS NORRACOTT gives POIROT a sharp, suspicious look, a snatching the lingerie away from him starts to pack it in the wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: (sharply) Was there something, sir?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I understand that you were on duty on this floor between eleven and twelve o'clock this morning.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Not after eleven thirty I wasn't. I had to go to a staff meeting didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Well, before you left for your meeting did you hear the sound of a typewriter coming from Captain Marshall's bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Yes. I heard him typing away quite steady. POIROT's gaze travels to a huge array of cosmetic bottles up on the dressing table. Identifiable but not over promi is a bottle of perfume labelled Souffle De Mer.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Now I want you to take a look at these botties. Can you tell me if any are missing? She stares helplessly at them.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Lord sir, you'd have to have the memory of an h'elephant to be able to tell that.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: What about the other rooms, where I pre- sume there are somewhat fewer bottles?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: I can't say I noticed nothing. What kind of a bottle might it be?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Alas that I cannot tell you. Eh maintenant, one last thing I want you to cast about in your mind to see if there is anything odd that you can remember as having happened  104 Continued She looks 98 POIROT (Cont) this morning which you might have noticed, and have forgotten to tell us.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Odd sir?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Yes, Gladys. Odd. Unusual. Out of place. Different to the normal run of things. at him with a doltish expression on her face. POIROT waits patiently. She looks

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Well there was one thing, though it was nothing really. Just someone having a bath a bit after twelve o'clock. I mean that's odd or unusual isn't it? Most people have baths in the early morning or in the evening, but not in the middle of the day.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Who had this bath?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: I reelly couldn't say. I just heard it going down the waste that's all.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You're sure it was a bath - not one of the hand basins?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Quite sure. I mean you can't mistake bath water running away, now can you? It makes a kind of gurgling sound.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Like someone choking?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS NORRACOTT
dialogues.text: Sort of, yes.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Or being strangled? at bim wide-eyed, her hand flying to her mouth. DAPHNE CASTLE appears in the doorway, and sees only GLADY

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Do get on with your work Gladys. You're not paid to gawp.  99 104 Continued GLADYS NORRACOTT hurries out. DAPHNE CASTLE now sees POIR

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Oh it's you Monsieur Poirot.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: A votre service, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's no use questioning Gladys about anything. She's as dense as dough.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I have not found it so, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Really? Well have you arrested anyone yet? I told you who it was.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Your choice of murderer has so far been somewhat extensive.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Has it? Well I can’t stop now and sort it out for you. I've simply got to keep an eye on Andrea. He's making a curry de Poulet Vindaloos for dinner, and the last time he cooked it, it was s0 hot we practically had to call the fire brigade from the mainland. Arriverdutch as they say in Holland.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Au revoir encore Madame. She bustles out. RACE and POIROT follow slowly.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: She's quite potty. She’1l be accusing us next.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Do not distress yourself about Madame Castle, mon vieux. Order and method will prevail.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I sincerely hope so, but then why all these irrelevant questions of yours about baths and bottles? They walk through the door.  105 INT. 106 100

dialogues.speaker: THE MAIN LANDING OF THE HOTEL EVENING
dialogues.text: POIROT and RACE walk out onto the main -landing.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: There is nothing irrelevant about my questions, je vous assure. They are eminently the most logical. If you have an empty bottle on your dressing table, or in your bathroom, what do you do with it? Do you drop it in the waste paper basket, or do you go to the trouble of going out onto your balcony and hurling it into the sea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H'm, I see what you mean. You would only do that if you didn't want to be connected with it.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Exactement.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And the bath? What is so strange about the bath?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: The time - a little after twelve o'clock. Consider which of the guests were in the hotel at that hour. Madame Redfern. Monsieur Gardener. Madame Castle and Capitaine Marshall. They were all about to play tennis - a curious time to choose to take a bath, n'est ce pas? See you at le dejeuner. POIROT heads off to his room to change for dinner leaving RACE to descend the stairs thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: THE DINING ROOM OF THE HOTEL NIGHT
dialogues.text: All the guests are seated at the table eating the curried BERT and CHARLIE are the waiters in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: By George this is hot ~ but absolutely super!  o~ 106 Continued He laughs. 101

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: You're right. It's hotter than a night in a Mexican whorehouse. The others ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: I hope you're not going to be ill, Odell, like poor Mrs Auschsteiner- boltz's girl Sadie. Do you remember how she was when she ate the hot chillies in Alberquque?
