dialogues.speaker: MR GARDDNGR
dialogues.text: Dear, I thought it was Gazpachio in Mexico City.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: It was hot chillies in Alberquque, and all night long she was up and down to the john, which was about half a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Are you sure it wasn't an earth closet, Mrs Gardener? She smiles insouciantly at MRS GARDENER who glares back.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (to Bert) Could I please have a glass of iced water,

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Good idea. For me too please. About a gallon of it. A chorus of "Me toos". POIROT rises to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mesdames, Monsieurs, talking of water, I would like to disturb you all from the excellence of your dinner for a moment, by asking you just one simple question, which may have some bearing on our murder. Did any of you have a bath this morning about midday, or a few minutes later?  106 Continued 102 The CAMERA moves round the circle of faces, They all shak their heads. POIROT turns to RACE.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Voila! Another little mystery to torture the logical mind. A bath poured out, which no one will admit to taking. (to the Company) Please continue to consume the dish of the incomparable Andrea, and leave to my little grey cells the elucidation of the puzzle why cleanliness is not next to truthfulness. He taps his forehead and resume his seat as we FADE TO BL

dialogues.speaker: MIDDAY
dialogues.text: RACE is finishing strapping an apprehensive POIROT into a Bosun's chair on the cliff top. He crosses himself devoutly, as he is swung out over the side of the cliff a lowered by the SERGEANT. RACE himself descends into the b by the iron ladder clamped to the cliff face, enjoying as he does so the grotesque sight of his colleague swinging around in the air above his head like a helpless whale.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ma foie! Quelle vie de boheme!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (calling) What's that you say?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (testy) I said my liver! What a life of a Bohemian!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (calling) I wouldn't be worrying about Bohemians if I were you, at this moment. I'd just hang on tight. POIROT looks down and nearly faints with terror at the sh drop below his dangling feet.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Quel horreur!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Don't look down.  103 107 Continued RACE climbs smartly down the ladder singing blithely:

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: (singing) He flies through the air with the greatest of ease That daring vieux Belge on the flying trapeze.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais c'est bien impudent tout cela! RACE leaps off the ladder and is in time to catch the wil gyrating POIROT, and release him from his harness.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Well done Poirot. That should have juiced up the little grey cells for you.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: They have not been juiced. They have been paralysed. After considerable attention to his toilet POIROT recover himself enough to take an interest in his surroundings. A the sergeant descends the iron ladder, he walks over to t taped outline figure lying above the waterline in the sha of the overhanging cliff. The green Chinese hat lies over spot where the face would be, and the white bathing costu is spread out over the trunk of the body. He studies it intently. Behind him the sergeant picks up a couple of ob ‘from the beach.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: I have found these on the sand. He holds out a pair of scissors and a pipe stem. POIROT and RACE study them curiously.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Right. Hang on to them will you. (to Poirot) Do you think they're significant?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais oui. As significant as a wristwatch, a bathing cap, a bottle, a bath... The bell on the fishermen's chapel round the corner in Bi Bay. sounds twelve o'clock faintly: --- and the chapel bell. (he looks at his watch) Bon. It is’ precisely the same time as yesterday when the body was discovered.  104 107 Continued PATRICK REDFERN rows the boat with his passenger MISS BRE in the stern, round the point and in towards the shore. PATRICK REDFERN jumps out and runs up the beach.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Well done. You are precisely on time. Now remember you are to do exactly as. you did before.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: I shouted to her I think.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Good. Well off you go.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (shouting) Arlena! ... Arlena ... Hi there! PATRICK REDFERN runs on up the beach waving, and shouting Hi there Arlena ... He reaches the figure and kneels down beside it. Hey, wake up! PATRICK REDFERN touches one of the outline limbs and then sharply pulls his hand away as if stung. He lifts the hat the face.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (shouting) My God!

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: She's dead ... She's been murdered strangled! He drops the hat back to cover where the face would be an runs down to MISS BREWSTER who is sitting in the boat hol the oars.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Are you sure? PATRICK REDFERN nods his head dumbly. How horrible!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Who could have done this to Arlena? ... It's just not possible.  105 107 Continued 108 PATRICK REDFERN looks at POIROT who has been watching the reconstruction with great attention.

dialogues.speaker: . PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: We stayed like this for a minute or so. You see we were shocked. We didn't know what to do. Then in case the murderer was still hanging about, I volunteered to stay with the body while Miss Brewster went to fetch the police. I touched nothing other than to make sure she was dead.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: And I rowed away back to the hotel. I couldn't cope with that ladder you see.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I quite sympathise, Mademoiselle. POIROT walks thoughtfully about the cove examining the cl Suddenly he stops and beckons to RACE:

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (shouting) Come here Colonel. Look at this. RACE joins POIROT and sees what POIROT has found - a narr gap in the cliff face. They squeeze through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POIROT and RACE stand in the cave. It is faintly lit.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: H'm. The air's quite fresh. POIROT sniffs delicately.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Indeed. It smells of le Souffle De Mer.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: The breath of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: H'm. Very poetic. The two men look about them, examining the cave in detail Suddenly, POIROT looks at a shelf high above his head.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: One might perhaps see that there is nothing up there.  108 106 Continued RACE stretches up a long arm, but is still too short for effective search by about a foot. Somewhat precariously h manages a toe-hold in the cave wall, and hoisting himself is now able to investigate the shelf properly. Suddenly h whistles and descends abruptly. In his hands is a tin box labelled Sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Ah a picnic box.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: A curious place to hide the egg and cress sandwiches, would you not say, mon vieux? RACE opens the box. WE TRACK in to a CLOSE UP to see that the various compartments, labelled Salt, Pepper and Musta are all full of what looks like salt. RACE wets a finger and tastes some.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Good God! ... Not egg and cress, Poirot. Heroin! ... So my information was correct ... What a lucky break! The fellow I've been looking for is obviously using this place as a drop or a cache.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: What a fortunate find, mon cher. Now all you have to do is have a watch kept and you will soon know who it is

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Exactly. It will give that idle Sergeant of mine something to do. RACE puts the sandwich box back where he found it. You know, I've been thinking. It could be that Mrs Marshall was an addict, and came here yesterday morning to meet’ her supplier.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Non. Non. Non. It is not possible. She had steady nerves, and radiant health. But of course there is always the possibility that she discovered this business accidentally and was Silenced. Alons. Let us return to the hotel. POIROT and RACE leave the cove.  107

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 POIROT and RACE emerge from the cave. POIROT looks first the bosun's harness and then at the poat. Each object dra a shudder from him.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Alas, I stand between the Scylla of Vertigo, and the Charybdis of Mal De Mer. (he shrugs massively) It is true one does not die of Mal De Mer, whereas another journey in that infernal machine might well induce une crise des nerfs from which I would never recover. (to Patrick Redfern) Would you permit me, Monsieur, to prevail on Mademoiselle Brewster for your place in her boat.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Please go ahead. I'11 use the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: You are too amiable. PATRICK REDFERN gives POIROT a dazzling smile and walks a across the beach towards the ladder. He is followed by RA POIROT meanwhile walks apprehensively down the beach towa the boat, in the company of Miss Brewster.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: All you have to do is to hop in Monsieur Poirot, and leave everything else to me. Gingerly he complies with her suggestion. As soon as he i settled she casts off, and jumps into’ the boat making it lurch sickeningly. As POIROT groans unhappily she bends t the oars. Back on the beach the sergeant conceals himself unhappily behind a rock. The CAMERA TRACKS to ECU outline figure on the sand. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONSERVATORY DAY
dialogues.text: ECU model replica of Blood Bay. A hand comes into shot an places a marker with Arlena Marshall's name on it, in the middle of it. We PULL BACK to see POIROT leaning over the model. RACE stands watching.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Now from my own unhappy experience I know it takes about twenty five minutes to row from Booty Beach to Blood Bay, so it is clear Madame Marshall arrived there at approximately five minutes past eleven. Between then and twelve o'clock, she was  108 110 Continued POIROT (Cont) murdered. Let us see where everybody claims to have been during those fifty five minutes. As he speaks each suspect's name, he places their marker the appropriate time also written on it, in the relevant place, sometimes using two markers when the person named from one place to another, during the period under review

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Capitaine Marshall was in his room typing. Monsieur and Madame Gardener were on Booty Beach until eleven forty when Monsieur Gardener returned to the hotel leaving his wife alone. Monsieur Redfern was on Booty Beach until he left with Mademoiselle Brewster to go for a row a little before eleven thirty. Mademoiselle Brewster herself arrived at Booty Beach about eleven twenty after exercising in her room. Madame Castle was at Lighthouse Ledge until she returned for her staff meeting here at the hotel at eleven thirty. Madame Redfern and Mademoiselle Marshall were here at Cutlass Cove until twelve o'clock, when Madame Redfern left to go back to the hotel, leaving Mademoiselle Linda alone. Finally Monsieur Blatt was out here sailing in a South Westerly direction. Now what does all that tell us? RACE points to the relevant markers.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: That the only people with watertight alibis are Captain Marshall with his hour's typing, Mr Redfern who was either in your sight, or Miss Brewster's. and Mrs Redfern and Linda Marshall who vouch for each other,

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Exactement, and nearly everybody had a motive for killing her.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: The exception being Mr Blatt.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And even he for an innocent man seems to be very nervous,

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Poirot I must confess to you that I find this whole case most baffling. Have you any idea who it is?  110 1il 112 109 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POTROT
dialogues.text: I know who it should be. As I told you before, this is a very slick crime. Something tells me it is not a first attempt.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I follow you.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Come let us take the little promenade and I will explain. MIX THROUGH to next scene

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BIBLE BAY DAY
dialogues.text: POIROT and RACE walk down the promontory to the Fishermen Chapel.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I must tell you, that earlier this year I was retained by the Trojan Insurance Company to investigate a case of strangul- ation which the police were satisfied was the work of a madman or tramp, and not of the obvious suspect - the husband who ben- efited from the Insurance Policy. I read the documents and decided it was useless to investigate, because the husband had an obviously cast iron alibi, being on a train miles away at the time of the murder. Now suddenly I am not so sure, that incredible as it may seem, I Hercule Poirot, did not make the bad mistake. He looks crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Come on Poirot. You mustn't reproach yourself. We all make mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Oh really Poirot! Sometimes you are impossible. They enter the Chapel, with RACE laughing and POIROT affr

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE SEAMEN'S CHAPEL BIBLE BAY DAY
dialogues.text: The interior of the Chapel is small and ancient, carved o of stone and crossed with rough wooden tiles. A cross POI watched by the still chuckling RACE stops to examine a sc illustrating the parable of the talents made out of shell  110 112 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (frosty) Ah, the Parable of the Talents. I'm sure you have always believed, that unto everyone that hath shall be given, but from him who hath not shall be taken away, haven't you cher Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Have I Poirot?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais Naturellement, Surely you have always known that to he who doesn't enquire, nothing shall be revealed. Par example, you should enquire what the Insurance Company case has to do with this one, instead of laughing like the jack hass.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Poirot. I really am. Perhaps you would be good enough to explain. POIROT is mollified by RACE's apology and he graciously consents to explain while the CAMERA examines carvings of skulls and gargoyles, martyrs and devils in a short bizar montage.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Can't you see they share the same pattern - the cold blooded plotting, the strangulation, the cast iron alibi of the husband. Mon vieux, I want you to do something for me. I want you to get me photographs of all the witnesses in that case - the husband, the hiker who found the body, everybody who was interviewed. The name of the murdered woman was Alice Corrigan. Her husband's name I think was Edward, and the crime took place near Ilkley, Yorkshire.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: That shouldn't be too difficult. The Police probably won't have any photo- graphs but the local press would almost certainly have taken some at the Inquest.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Good. I would also like to have a report on the financial affairs of the murdered woman.  111 112 Continued 113 114

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I don't think I will be able to get you any of this information before tomorrow evening, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Do not distress yourself, mon cher. While we wait we will amuse ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Amuse ourselves?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Absolument. We shall have un grand pique-nique. RACE stares at POIROT in astonishment, as the chapel bell strikes the hour.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, OPEN COUNTRYSIDE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: DAPHNE CASTLE and POIROT lead the way through open countr They are followed by the two male servants BERT and CHARL in uniform, carrying hampers. Behind them come the guests MR and MRS GARDENER, MISS BREWSTER, MR and MRS REDFERN, KENNETH and LINDA MARSHALL. MR BLATT walks at the rear by himself. The procession moves. into more thickly wooded countryside. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GLADE WITH STREAM AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The procession of guests and servants enter a wooded glad through which runs a stream, and over which is a narrow wooden bridge. POIROT spreads his arms wide, and indicate he is satisfied with the venue.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Voila, mesdames, messieurs. A perfect place for le dejeuner, sur l'herbe.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I suppose Andrea's splendid Goose Pie might as well be ravished by ants here, as elsewhere and me too for that matter!

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Do you remember Odell when we were given those Reindeer Marrow Bones at Modesty Tausburphimmel's home in Pittsburgh?  112 114 Continued 115

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: I thought they were elk bones, dear.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: They were Reindeer Bones, and they were charred black. I remember particularly as there wasn't a thing to eat on them. No wonder she keeps her figure.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Well I'n not going to worry about my figure today, Daddy. I'm going to gorge myself silly.

dialogues.speaker: . KENNETH MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Quite right, darling. I'm sure Daphne would be most offended if you didn't. KENNETH MARSHALL and DAPHNE CASTLE exchange meaningful glances. The guests spread out and the servants BERT and CHARLIE start to unpack the hampers supervised by DAPHNE CASTLE. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GLADE WITH STREAM LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: It 1s a couple of hours later. Many of the company are asleep or resting in their previous groupings. BERT and CHARLIE are packing up the plates and cutlery. POIROT has crossed the river, and is sitting, comfortably replet beneath a tree. He yawns, stretches, and suddenly gets to his feet, as his attention is caught by a large spread of Datura. He next sees CHRISTINE REDFERN walking on the other side of the river and calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (calling) Ah Madame Redfern, come and look at these flowers. Ils sont tres extraordinaires!  113 ao 115 Continued 116 CHRISTINE REDFERN runs across the narrow wooden bridge. S joins POIROT and PATRICK REDFERN and examines the flowers

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: They're very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And pretty deadly, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Really? ...What are they?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Les Trompettes De La Mort.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: The trumpets of death?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Exactement, Monsieur. Datura. A highly toxic solanaceous plant. Paralysis and death occur with quite astounding swiftness. Yes - all in all, a most lethal weapon ... CHRISTINE REDFERN, who has been about to touch the flower draws back her hand sharply.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: . and a most successful picnic don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Oh ves, very, even thougn there's stiti a murderer walking about loose among us.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: For not much longer, Mousieur, Croyez-moi. The CAMERA moves to a CLOSE UP of the Datura flowers. We MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: KEELHAUL CAVES EVENING
dialogues.text: POIROT walks about, deep in thought, amongst the jumble o rocky caverns which form Keelhaul Caves. Suddenly he is hailed by RACE who comes hurrying across the shingle towa

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Ah Poirot. I've been looking ail over for you.  114 116 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Sometimes it is necessary to repose the mind in solitude. One must not blame the little grey cells for their moments of misanthropy.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Well, did you have a good picnic?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: lt was most illuminating, and in a certain way quite surprising.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Really? In what way may one ask?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Gastronomically. The Goose Pie was merveilleuse. Have you any news?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Yes. Whilst you have been surprising your stomach, I have been finding out about Mrs Marshall's financial affairs. In a nutshell her bank told me that out of the hundred thousand pounds left to her last year, she has drawn out in cash amounts all but eight thousand. To my mind, this certainly confirms the blackmail story.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Ah ca c'est tres interressant!...And the photographs? When may I expect them?

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I should have them tomorrow morning. They will be radioed to Tirane and brought here.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Bon. I am convinced they will prove my case.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: So now you know who it is?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Yes. I know.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Well?  116 117 118 115 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I do not like to speak until I have the proof.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: How about a clue then?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mais certainement. It is not as you might expect from your study of detective fiction, the least likely person. Au contraire. It is the most likely person. He smiles disarmingly as we MIX THROUGH TO the next scene

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLOOD BAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: A shadowy figure climbs down the cliff ladder at Blood Ba and crosses the stretch of sand to the concealed entrance to the cave. It finds it and slips inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAVE NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the dim light, the figure crosses to the shelf, and ma use of the toe hole in the cave wall reaches up and searc the shelf. Two powerful police torches suddenly stab out the darkness and light up MR BLATT as he grasps the sandw box.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Bon soir, Monsieur Blatt. Have you come here to tell us one of your so’ amusing stories? MR BLATT spins round and tumbles down from the perch into arms of the SERGEANT. POIROT rises from a shooting stick. He is elaborately muffled against the night's chill.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Christ Almighty!!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: What's it to be this time? Something spicy about dope running?

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. It's a fair cop. But how you found out, beats me.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: If it's any consolation to you, it was a bit of luck really. We do get them every so often you know.  118 119 116 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Moi I am always interested in the activities of lone sailors, particularly ones who are fascinated by pirates and smuggling.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Me and my big mouth! Well, at least you can't hang me for it.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Pour quoi pas? It gives you a good motive for murdering Madame Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: What!!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: You ran your stuff in here. She caught you at it, and threatened to blow the gaff and you topped her.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Now look guv'ner, you can't pin murder on me. That's not my game. I swear I never even spoke to the lady, let alone laid a finger on her. You've got to believe me.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Believe the word of a heroin smuggler - why should I? What do you think Poirot?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I think you should hold him here until tomorrow, when all shall be revealed. Meanwhile even a Hercule Poirot becomes fatigued, so perhaps you would be so amiable as to row me back to the hotel - with as much stateliness as you can command. POIROT leaves the cave followed by RACE and the SERGEANT, the latter taking a firm grip on the cowed figure of MR B

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests of the Jolly Roger Hotel sit round facing the fireplace in a large semi-circle. MR and MRS GARDENER sit to the right of the fireplace, and next to them in order are KENNETH MARSHALL, LINDA MARSHALL, DAPHNE CASTLE, PATRICK and CHRISTINE REDFERN, MISS BREWSTER, and last of all to the left of the fireplace HORACE BLATT. Behind  119 120 117 Continued MR BLATT stands the SERGEANT. There is a general excited buzz of conversation which is suddenly stilled as HERCULE POIROT enters the room and takes his place in the centre the semi-circle, standing before the model of Smugglers' Island which has been moved from the conservatory into th lounge.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Mesdames, Messieurs, I have asked you all to meet me here this morning, because I have discovered the identity of the murderer of Madame Marshall. There is a further buzz of surprised conversation, and POIROT takes a small bow.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: It is at the moment only a theory, - though one which I am quite sure is. the correct one. However, thanks to the good offices of my dear colleague Colonel Race, I am hoping that certain proofs will arrive shortly, which will put the matter beyond doubt. Meanwhile I shall, with your kind permission offer you Hercuie Poirot's solution. Another buzz of affirmation.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Eh bien, let us begin with a reconstruction of the events at Blood Bay at the time of the murder. We MIX THROUGH TO the next scene, as POIROT points with a pencil to Blood Bay on the model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene is a flashback to scene 107. POIROT is examinin the taped figure lying above the waterline in the shade of the overhanging cliff, watched by RACE and the BERGEAN The green Chinese hat lies over the spot where the face w be, and the white bathing costume is spread out over the trunk of the body. PATRICK REDFERN and MISS BREWSTER arri in the rowing boat, and the former runs up the beach and goes through his reconstruction, kneeling by the outline figure, lifting the hat off the face, then replacing it and running down the beach towards MISS BREWSTER in the boat.  118 120 Continued 121

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I visited the scene of the crime at twelve noon the following day, that is to say the same time the body was discovered. I was struck at once by one very interesting fact. Madame Marshall had been obviously lying in the shade. And yet as I learned from the reconstruction her face had been covered by her great big green Chinese hat. Why, I asked myself was her face shielded from a non- existent sun? There could only be one answer - the murderer had wanted it concealed. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT, RESIDENTS' LOUNGE HOTEL MID-DAY
dialogues.text: The scene is the same as it was at the end of scene 119. RACE enters holding an envelope which he waves affirmativ at POIROT. They nod at each other.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: But why mes amis had the murderer wanted it concealed? He looks directly at PATRICK REDFERN who stirs uneasily i chair.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: 1 think you know very well why, Monsieur Redfern.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: What can you mean?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I mean that everyone here at this hotel had the opportunity to kill Madame Marshall, except for you and Madame Redfern. She hadn't got the opportunity because she was with Mademoiselle Linda in Cutlass Cove. (he points to Cutlass Cove on the model) And you hadn't got the opportunity since, as you correctly informed me,  121 Continued 119 POIROT (Cont) 1 was your alibi during the whole time until you left the harbour with Miss Brewster, to row rouna@ the Island. He points to Booty Beach and the Harbour on the model.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Well there you are then. If we are the least suspicious of all the people here, why should I know why the murderer had wanted to conceal Arlena'’s face with the hat?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Because the singular impossibility of you and your wife having done the crime, convinces me beyond doubt that you actually did do it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: What!! Is it daft you are?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so Monsieur Redfern. ft is my belief that Arlena Marshall went to Blood Bay to meet you, and that she did meet you, and that you killed her there as you planned to do! PATRICK REDFERN bounds to his feet

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Jesus. You re talking through your hat- POIROT shakes his head slowly. D‘you mind telling me how J did it then?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Hercule Poirot 1s not to be fooled twice, mon petit assassin. You did it an the same way that you murdered Alice Corrigan at llkley earlier this year,with the able assistance of your wite or partner Christine, who helped you here, in the same way as she helped you then, by pretending to discover the body of Alice Corrigan at least twenty minutes before Alice Corrigan actually died, and while you were still on the train.  120 4121 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (suddenly furious) Lies! .,. All bloody lies!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Calm yourself, Patrick. As he said himself he can't prove anything. It's only a theory.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: What about this proof of his that's coming eh? What about that now?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: Don't let him fool you. He just said that to get you to talk. Can't you see that?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Quite right girl. Let him blather away. (ironic) Pray continue, Monsieur Poirot.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Merci. Vous est trop gentil ...Let me say at once that the crime depended 6n the character of Madame Marshall. From the start I saw she was the archetypal victim. It wasn't she who fatally attracted men. It was men like you who fatally attracted her - an adventurer, a man of good looks and easy assurance who makes his living out of women, and often ends up killing them. In other words you were the most likely suspect.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (hotly) Now that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: (warningly) Patrick! PATRICK REDFERN relaxes, grinning boyishly.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: I have no doubt in my mind, Monsieur Redfern, that you found it quite easy to get Arlena Marshall to hand you large sums of money from time to time, for "investment", That was how she lost her money, wasn't it? There was  121 122 121 Continued POIROT (Cont) no blackmailer, nor never was. She was a pure invention of your wife's to account for her depleted bank account. PATRICK and CHRISTINE REDFERN exchange uneasy glances.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: If anything at all of what you're saying were true, d'you mind telling me why on earth I should kill her. Presumably there would have been plenty more where that came from.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Not so, mon ami. There was very little left. And it wasn't going to be very long before her husband was going to start asking awkward questions about who had swindled her. She would have told him, so you had to kill her in order to avoid a long speil in jail. N'est ce pas? PATRICK REDFERN shrugs carelessly.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: It's a tale for the little people, Monsieur Poirot. Why don't you show me how I did it, if you're so clever?

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: As I say, you did it with the aid of this woman here, who may or may not be your wife. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashback to scene 29. PATRICK and CHRISTINE REDFERN stand by an open window, in their bedroom, rowing loudly over his attentions to Arlena Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: From the moment you came here both of you played out a series of care- fully rehearsed scenes in such a manner that all might hear, or see. Together there were scenes of hysterical jealousy, boomed out through open windows ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  123 124 125 126 122

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: A flashback to scene 22. POIROT and MISS BREWSTER are talking together and are joined by CHRISTINE REDFERN. The recessed dialogue we hear is from "I suppose it's a bit like heights. Some people can't stand them ..." to "I don go brown, I just become like a cassata - pink skin, white blisters and green in the face".

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . Apart, you Madame, took every opportunity to give the impression that you were a physically frail woman who was absolutely terrified of heights, and who had to hide her skin away from the sun, because it blistered and made her look like an Italian ice cream ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE ARBOUR OVERLOOKING BIBLE BAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: A flashback to scene 34. CHRISTINE REDFERN is sitting on stone bench in the Arbour, crying on Poirot's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... and who was altogether to be pitied as a poor little, helpless abandoned wife. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A TREE SCREENED CLEARING NIGHT
dialogues.text: A flashback to scene 36 ARLENA MARSHALL and PATRICK REDFERN stand close together in the glade declaring their love for each other, and embracing passionately.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . Whilst you, Monsieur, took elaborately indiscreet pains to advertise your romance, by virtually shouting declarations of love, instead of whispering sweet nothings ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOOTY BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: A flashback to scene 46. PATRICK REDFERN impatiently paces the beach turning his head continually in the direc of the hotel.  126 127 128 123 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. and pacing moodily about like a sulky love-lorn poet. But as I say I was convinced the pair of you were play acting, and 1 was determined to prove it, by finding you Madame, out in a perfectly obvious lie. To this end I arranged une pique nique ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GLADE WITH STREAM LATS AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A flashback to scene 115 POIROT is examining the Datura flowers. He sees CHRISTINE REDFERN walking on the other side of the river, and calls to her. CHRISTINE REDFERN runs across the narrow wooden bridge. She joins POIROT and examines the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: POTROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. and during the course of it induced you to cross a narrow bridge over running water which I had previously selected. If it were true you had a bad head for heights you would have had a great difficulty crossing that bridge. Madame, I must tell you, I saw no such difficulty. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE RESIDENTS' LOUNGE HOTEL MID-DAY
dialogues.text: The company are grouped as they were at the end of scene CHRISTINE REDFERN is looking murderously at POIROT.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: That means nothing. I was in a hurry, and probably didn't take notice.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: lf your affliction had been genuine you could not have helped taking notice. But it was not, and I knew you were lying about it, and I also knew why.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE REDFERN
dialogues.text: (shouting) Then why for God's sake?  128 129 130 124 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: If you only have patience Madame, I will now describe to you what you both did. (to Patrick Redfern) The first move you made was on the beach on the day previous to the murder ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene as he points to the terrace above the hotel beach on the model.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TERRACE ABOVE THE BATHING BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: A flashback to scene 24, We pick up the scene where CHRISTINE REDFERN gets to her feet and waves to her husba in the distance. We see him pause, then ignore the wave, and deliberately walk off with ARLENA MARSHALL down the beach. Abruptly CHRISTINE REDFERN turns and leaves the terrace, heading back towards the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: -.. You arranged a clandestine meeting with Arlena Marshall in Blood Bay, for the following day. She was to go round to the Bay early. Nobody went there in the morning when it was in shade, and you were to join her there as soon as you could slip away undetected. You told her that if, while she was waiting for you, she heard anyone descending the ladder, or a boat came in sight, she was to Slip into the cave ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: PATRICK REDFERN creeps furtively out of the hotel, using the outside staircase. He is wearing a bathing wrap, unde which he is holding something bulky. He runs off in the direction of Blood Bay.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. You left the hotel early in the morning, and ran over to Blood Bay. Under your bathing wrap you had concealed a green Chinese hat - the duplicate of the one Arlena Marshall was in the habit of wearing ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  131 132 133 134 125

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLOOD BAY EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: PATRICK REDFERN climbs the ladder into the Cove. He then takes the Chinese hat from under his wrap and conceals it behind a rock, and climbs up the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .:» You climbed down the ladder and stowed it away in an appropriate place, out of sight, before returning to the hotel. In the meantime you, Madame Christine had gone to Linda Marshall's room ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LINDA MARSHALL'S BEDROOM MORNING
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN enters LINDA MARSHALL‘'s bedroom and al her wristwatch, putting it fifteen minutes forward - an action we see in CLOSE UP.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: , and advanced her wristwatch by fifteen minutes. LINDA MARSHALL enters the room and the rest of the scene flashback to scene 42

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . You then arranged the expedition to Cutlass Cove and returned to your own room ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene. INT. PATRICK AND CHRISTINE. REDFERN’S BEDROOM MORNING CHRISTINE REDFERN applies dark sun tan to her legs and ar She then throws the bottle out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: +». where you carefully stained your vaunted white arms and legs with dark sun tan and then threw the incriminating bottle out of the window ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashback to scene 90. MISS BREWSTER is swimming. The sun tan bottle comes hurtling out of the sky and lands with a great splash near to her. It fills with water and sinks. MISS BREWSTER looks up angrily at the hotel windows but i  134 135 136 137 126 Continued unable to discover from which window it has been thrown, because the sun is in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... where it narrowly escaped hitting Mademoiselle Brewster who was bathing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PATRICK AND CHRISTINE REDFERN'S BEDROOM MORNING
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN is putting on a white bathing suit simi to Arlena Marshall's. Over it she puts on a pair of beach pyjamas.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: _... You then dressed yourself in a white bathing costume similar to the one worn by Arlena Marshall, and over it a pair of garish beach pyjamas with long floppy sleeves and a high neck, which effectually concealed your newly browned limbs and chest. You then went off to Cutlass Cove with Linda while 1 made my way to Rooty Beach ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOOTY BEACH MORNING
dialogues.text: Flashback to scene *2 from where ARLENA MARSHALL paddles away on her float to where PATRICK REDFERN arrives, and looks about him, puzzled and impatient.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... At about eleven forty Madame Marshall departed for her rendezvous. and a minute or two later you Monsieur Redfern appeared, and after some laboriously comic remarks about my suede shoes, you set about registering baffled impatience. And now, mes amis the scene moves to Cutlass Cove... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashback to an amalgam of scenes 68 and 75, this time shot from a neutral position. The action is from whe LINDA MARSHALL rises and CHRISTINE REDFERN asks the time to where LINDA MARSHALL enters the sea and CHRISTINE REDF leaves the cove - only this time we see in CU CHRISTINE REDFERN picking up LINDA MARSHALL'S watch which she has t  137 138 139 127 Continued ‘ off and left behind her on her first visit to the sea (be being reminded of the bathing cap), and putting the hands back fifteen minutes to 11.45.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . At eleven forty five, and keeping her own watch concealed, Madame Christine asked Linda the time. Naturally she said it was twelve o'clock. She then starts to go down to the sea. While her back is turned, Madame Christine returns the watch to the correct time. Then she calls Linda back telling her she has forgotten her bathing cap. Why should she bother to do that, you may ask? The answer is simple, On top of the Fisherman's Chapel in Bibie Bay, there is a bell. Fifteen minutes later it was due to strike the hour, and if Linda heard it the game would be up. True, as I knew from Mr Blatt's evidence that the wind was South West, and therefore blowing away from her, but Madame Christine could take no - chances of the sound carrying. A girl splashing about in the sea and wearing a bathing cap would hear nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN looks down and waves to LINDA MARSHALL in the sea. She waves back. CHRISTINE REDFERN now strikes Westward along the path to Booty Bay, rather than Southwa to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now she hurries from the cove ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN runs as fast as she can along the path which separates Cutlass Cove from Blood Bay. Over it we see superimposed POIROT's finger tracing the journey on t model.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ... and over the path which separates Cutlass Cove from Blood Bay. This takes her about four minutes. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  140 141 128 EXT. TOP OF BLOOD BAY MiD-DAY CHRISTINE REDFERN strips off her beach pyjamas and puts them and her sketching things behind a rock. She then climbs agilely down the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . She then strips off her beach pyjamas, and hides them and her sketching things behind a big rock which is there, and climbs athletically down the ladder ... ‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARLENA MARSHALL is on the beach. She sees CHRISTINE REDFE descending the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: (to herself sotto vote) Christ! She runs into the cave.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Arlena Marshall is on the beach, wondering why you, Monsieur Redfern are taking so long to come. Suddenly to her great chagrin, she sees you, Madame, coming down the ladder. Only her husband could have presented a more inconvenient figure. Of course she is forced to take refuge in the cave ... CHRISTINE REDFERN takes the green Chinese hat from its hi place behind the rock, pulls out a false red curl from in it, and lies down on the beach above the water line. She arranges the hat over face so that it is hidden, and the curl shows to advantage.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .».-Then all you had to do was to take the green Chinese hat, with I suspect a false red curl pinned underneath the brim at the back, from where your > partner had hidden it earlier in the morning, and dispose yourself in a sprawling attitude with the hat and curl shielding your face and neck. All this has taken you at the very most a further five minutes. The timing is perfect. <A few minutes later the church bell strikes twelve o'clock,  141 129 Continued POIROT (V.0. Cont) and the boat containing Mademoiselle Brewster and Monsieur Redfern comes round the point ... From CHRISTINE REDFERN'S P.O.V. we see the row boat conta MISS BREWSTER and PATRICK REDFERN come round the point. He jumps out, runs up the beach waving and shouting, and kneels down beside the body. We see the bronzed limbs, the white bathing suit, the red hair curling out from under the brim of the Green Chinese hat from HIS POINT OF VIEW. He touches one of the bronzed arms, then pulls his hand away as if stung. He then lifts the hat off the face. In EXTREME CLOSE UP we see CHRISTIN REDFERN's face. She winks up at PATRICK. He grins broadly before replacing the hat, and starting his dialogue with BREWSTER.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It is of course Monsieur Redfern who runs up the beach, who bends down to examine the body. It is he who is stunned, shocked, broken by the death of his lover. All Mademoiselle Brewster had seen was a body with sun tanned limbs, wearing a white bathing costume and Arlena's hat. Do you remember what I said the first day we met, Mademoiselle? All bodies lying on the beach are alike. They're not men and women There is nothing personal about them They are like rows of butchers’ meat grilling in the sun, And it’s true. One moderately well made young woman is very like another. Two brown arms; two brown legs; and a little piece of bathing suit in between. MISS BREWSTER starts to run off back to-the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: POLROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... No wonder you were fooled into imagining that you had seen the corpse of Madame Marshall, when what you had actually seen was the live body of Madame Christine Redfern. Oui, that was why the murderer had to conceal the face - because it was not the murder victim lying there, but somebody else. And who else would help Monsieur Redfern but his own partner, or wife. Yes, the crime had the same pattern as the  141 142 130 Continued POIROT (V.O. Cont) Corrigan murder, with the victim being killed later than everyone thought possible. And now the performance by the witness is over. She has been chosen well, She has not got a good head for heights, 50 will not attempt to climb up the ladder. She will leave the Bay by boat, taking the long way back for help, and leaving Monsieur Redfern to remain with the body in case "the murderer was still hanging about". And what do you think happened Mademoiselle Brewster, as soon as you disappeared? ... As soon as the boat is out of sight CHRISTINE REDFERN jum up and cuts the hat into pieces with a pair of scissors, which she drops in her haste. She then fills the prassier of her bathing suit with the pieces of cardboard. Quickly she kisses PATRICK, then turns, runs across to the ladder swarms up it, and disappears. PATRICK REDFERN tosses a broken pipe stem down on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... Madame Christine jumps to her feet, cuts up the green cardboard hat into pieces she can conveniently stuff into her bathing costume, and swarms up the ladder. The only clues they leave for us are the pair of scissors which I'm sure she dropped unintentionally, and the pipe stem of Capitaine Marshall's pipe which they put there in the hope that it would incriminate him...

dialogues.speaker: EXT, CLIFF TOP ABOVE BLOOD BAY MID-DAY
dialogues.text: On the cliff top CHRISTINE REDFERN puts on her beach pyja gathers up her sketching materials, waves gaily to PATRIC below, and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. On the cliff top she slips back into her beach pyjamas gathers up her sketching things ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.  143 144 145 146 147 131

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE PATH BETWEEN BLOOD BAY AND CUTLASS COVE MID-DAY
dialogues.text: MONTAGE of shots of CHRISTINE REDFERN running down the path which leads between Blood Bay and Cutlass Cove.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... and runs back to the hotel as fast as she can ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE OF SHOTS of CHRISTINE REDFERN running down the pa which leads between Cutlass Cove and the hotel. Superimpo over both scenes is POIROT's finger tracing a course on t model. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE REDFERN runs into the hotel. The CAMERA TRACKS up to a window to see MR GARDENER looking out.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . where she is seen arriving between twelve ten, and twelve fifteen, by Mr Gardener ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene. INT. CHRISTINE REDFERN'’S BATHROOM/BEDROOM MID-DAY CHRISTINE REDFERN 1s briskly rubbing the sun tan off her body, in the bath. She dries herself quickly, flushes the pieces of green cardboard and curl down the lavatory, and walks next door to change into tennis clothes.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ... Here she takes the bath that no one would admit to taking, in order to wash off the sun tan, flushes the pieces of green cardboard hat and the curl down le lavabo, and is ready to gc to the Court MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashback of scene 79. CHRISTINE REDFERN hurries onto the tennis court, where KENNETH MARSHALL and DAPHNE CASTLE are knocking up against MR GARDENER, and walks over to jo him.  147 148 132 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. late it is true, but unruffled and smiling ... But what meanwhile has been happening to her partner Monsieur Patrick? ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATRICK REDFERN waves to his wife on the cliff top, as sh waves to him, She runs off and he moves swiftly over to t cave.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: All clear darling. ARLENA MARSHALL emerges from the cave.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: My God, you took an age.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry darling. It was difficult to slip away with your husband prowling about the place like a grizzly bear with a bad case of eczema. And then of course, my damned wife had to turn up here.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I know. I saw her. She absolutely amazed me. She came down that ladder like Tarzan. What on earth was she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: I don't know, but I sent her away with a flea in her ear. She won't be Mrs Patrick Redfern for very much longer - that I can promise you.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENA MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Dahling ... I've been so lonely ... They kiss. PATRICK REDFERN's hands slip up her back and fasten round her neck in a sudden deadly stranglehold. Her eyes bulge; her tongue protrudes; her face plackens. Slowly she slips to the ground. Satisfied she is dead, PATRICK REDFERN picks her up and carries her over to wher CHRISTINE REDFERN had lain, and carefully arranges her limbs in the same position as she had adopted. Finally he puts her green cardboard hat over her face, teases out a  148 149 133 Continued curl of her red hair to lie in the same position as the false one, and with a self-satisfied emile sits down to wait for the Police.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... Why, as soon as madame Christine is out of sight, he runs over to the cave and calls Arlena's name. She emerges, leaving behind her the smell of her perfume Souffle de Mer, which I had seen on her dressing table in her bedroom, and the presence of which my excellent nose at once detected in the cave. Now, I daresay with many a serpentine endearment, he apologises for his lateness, and his wife's untimely appearance in the Bay. She relaxes, perhaps pouts a little, forgives him - an embrace, and suddenly Monsieur Patrick's hands are round her throat. It is the end of poor, foolish, beautiful, easily beguiled Arlena Marshall ... He then arranges her in the same position that his partner had occupied on the beach, then covers her face with her hat, and a curl of her red hair, and sits down confidently, to await the arrival of the Police ... MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene is the same as it was at the end of scene 128. All eyes are on HERCULE POIROT as he finishes his oration

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Voila Mesdames, Messieurs - l'histoire de le Meurtre de Madame Marshall. He bows theatrically as if expecting applause. PATRICK REDFERN bounds to his feet, his eyes blazing.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: (furious) You damned, interfering, self- satisfied, Froggie mountebank.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Un Mountebank Belgique, Monsieur, s'il vous plait. ©  149 150 134 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: Where's your proof then? Just answer me that. Where's your blasted proof? POIROT looks across at RACE enquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: I didn't want to interrupt you, Poirot, while you were in full flow, so to speak, but this arrived while you were talking. It's from Ilkley, Yorkshire. He takes the photograph from the envelope and hands it ov In CLOSE UP we see that it is a reproduction of a page of The Ilkley Examiner. It is headed Brutal Murder On The Mo and beneath are two photographs. One is of Patrick Redfer and is captioned The Husband Edward Corrigan. The other i of Christine Redfern and is captioned The Hiker. POIROT looks at them and smiles happily.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (to the Redferns) Iei mes braves. The proof that will hang the pair of you. PATRICK REDFERN and CHRISTINE REDFERN both look at the pa

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REDFERN
dialogues.text: And it will kill you too! With a murderous snarl he throws himself on POIROT and fastens his tingers round his throat. POIROT's eyes bulge out of his head as the trapped blood starts to blacken hi face. He goes limp. RACE and the SERGEANT finally manage to drag PATRICK REDFERN off POIROT, but it has taken time and the CAMERA TRACKS into an EXTREME CLOSE UP of his seemingly lifeless face. MIX THROUGH TO the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HARBOUR EVENING
dialogues.text: PATRICK, CHRISTINE REDFERN and HORACE BLATT sit handcuffe to Albanian policemen in a police leunch. The Albanian SERGEANT helps MRS BREWSTER aboard, carrying her suitcase She crosses to sit next to MR BLATT.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (to Blatt) I'm sorry you turned out to be a wrong ‘un. From the way you handled that yawl of yours, I'd have thought you'd have been pretty good in a row boat, once you'd mastered the oars.  150 151 135 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: Reminds me of the one about the oarsman's wedding, and the little nipper standing outside the church watching the happy coupie and their entourage walk out. under the line of crossed blades, and shouting to his mother " ‘ere mum, look at all them oars", and she belting him across the ‘ear ‘ole, and saying "Them ain't oars, silly, them’s bridesmaids". MISS BREWSTER laughs loudly. Surprised MR BLATT joins in.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I say, thatis funny! She takes his manacled hands in hers and gives him a comforting squeeze. He smiles at her gratefully, recognis the first time that anyone has actually laughed at one of jokes.

dialogues.speaker: MR BLATT
dialogues.text: God bless you. The CAMERA PANS up and ZOOMS in to the firures of RACE and POIROT sitting on the verandah above the sun terrace.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, VERANDAH ABOVE THE SUN TERRACE EVENING
dialogues.text: POIROT reclines on a chaise longue, his neck swathed in scarves. He looks very sorry for himself. RACE sits solicitously near him on a cane chair.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: And I must say again, Poirot, it was a@ masterly piece of detection. Quite masterly.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: (croaking) And I say again cher Colonel that your attempts to save me from the talons of Monsieur Redfern were slower than a paralysed tortoise, It is a miracle IT am here. Une veritable miracle!

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Oh I don't think it was quite as serious as all that.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Parbleu! I tell you there is nothing more serieux than the life of Hercule Poirot. He looks down on the terrace below.  152 153 136

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TERRACE DAY
dialogues.text: WR and MRS GARDENER cross the terrace, as usual in disput

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Let me try and explain it to you, Odell. Mrs Corrigan was killed before the time her husband could possibly have been there.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: No, my dear, I'm afraid you've got it wrong. It merely appeared that she was killed before the husband could have got there. Actually, like Mrs Marshall she was killed after the time when everyone thought She was dead.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Odell, I hope you're not contradicting me. She was killed before the time her husband could have been there.

dialogues.speaker: MR GARDENER
dialogues.text: (raising his voice) Goddammit woman, yes I am contradicting you. To say she was actually killed before the husband could have got there is to say that you don't under- stand anything of this whole darned business, Furthermore it is my opinion that it is the view of a stupid.inane.empty headed woman without a coherent thought in the whole ot her toggy brain. In other words, Myra, you have a mind of the clarity and consistency of Clam Chowder! MRS GARDENER is completely taken aback. Never in her life has her spouse talked to her in this manner. Then she sof capitulates and takes his arm affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: MRS GARDENER
dialogues.text: Yes dear. I'm sorry dear. You're quite right dear. She was killed after the time when everyone thought She was dead. MR GARDENER nods his head in satisfaction. They disappear round rhe corner, arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE VERANDAH ABOVE THE SUN TERRACE EVENING
dialogues.text: POIROT and RACE sit together laughing.  137 153 Continued

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Thus, mon cher, it is possible to say that there is reconciliation in all things, - even murder. DAPHNE CASTLE, carrying a covered dish emerges from the hotel onto the terrace, accompanied by KENNETH MARSHALL and LINDA MARSHALL.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I'll see you both at dinner, my darlings. I've just got to make sure that poor Monsieur Poirot is looked after properly. She kisses them both and hurries up to POIROT and RACE, as the MARSHALLS wave to them and move off the other way.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Monsieur Poirot, I have brought you a dish specially prepared by Andrea to tempt an invalid, - Le Crapaud En Trou! POIROT blanches.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: The Toad in the Hole? Ce n'est pas mangeable! She uncovers the dish.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Of course it is. It's a great English favourite - spicy sausage meat-in a light batter. My God, you don't think we eat amphibians like you people, do you? POIROT indicates his battered throat.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: Helas mon pauvre gorge will not allow me to consume it, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: Nonsense, of course it will. I'll cut it up so that even a baby could swallow it. She tucks his napkin into the folds of his scarves, and starts to cut up the dish. The boat hoots in the distance.  153 154 138 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: The boat is waiting so, I'll leave you to your delicious supper, Poirot. But let me just add that it has been an honour and a pleasure to work with you again.

dialogues.speaker: POIROT
dialogues.text: And for me too, mon brave Colonel. Au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: RACE
dialogues.text: Au revoir. He stoops, holding out his hand. POIROT ignores the hand, put instead embraces him on both cheeks, with loud smacki kisses. RACE goes bright scarlet, chokes dramatically, an takes his leave. POIROT smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNE CASTLE
dialogues.text: I can't really think why you're looking so pleased with yourself. I told you the Redferns did it all along. POIROT's smiling mouth drops open in astc shment and outr giving DAPHNE CASTLE the opportunity to ram a spoonful of Toad in the Hole into it.

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE FRAME
dialogues.text: MIX THROUGH TO the last scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WHOLE ISLAND EVENING
dialogues.text: An aerial shot of Smugglers’ Island basking peacefully in the last rays of the setting sun.
